Members with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To treat her husband's illness

loans.name: Loek

texts.en:
Loek V. is 41 years old. She is a rice farmer who also makes cakes to sell in her village to her neighbors. She started the business in 1987 and can earn an income of approximately $2.00 per day. She is a mother of three children, all of whom are in school. Her husband, Tem Sarith, is 45 years old and makes a living growing rice and is also a local chef for wedding parties or other ceremonies.The family lives in Pursat Province.

To begin a new business and enlarge an exiting business, V. would like to ask for a loan in part to buy equipment to make sugar cane juice for sale and in part to order ingredients to make cake to sell.

loans.use: To buy equipment to make sugar cane juice to sell.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị C.  năm nay 49 tuổi, gia đình chị  có 2 con đều đã trưởng thành.  Đầu năm 2008 chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán, kinh doanh hàng tạp hóa. Công việc kinh doanh ngày càng phát triển và đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị hiện nay với thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng 
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm các mặt hàng phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu dùng của bà con trong dịp Tết sắp tới.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị C. is 49 years old and has two grown children. At the beginning of 2008, she joined the TYM Fund and borrowed money to invest in a grocery shop. Her business is doing well so far and is now the main source of income for her family, earning about 2,500,000 VND (150 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to buy goods for her shop that will meet the needs of her customers during the upcoming Tet holiday (lunar new year, January 26, 2009).

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grocery store.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Lê Thị Thảo năm nay 39 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và  2 con nhỏ tại huyện Quảng Xương tỉnh Thanh Hóa. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ đầu năm  2008. Hiện tại  ngoài chăn nuôi và trồng trọt gia đình chị còn làm thêm nghề in chiếu với tổng thu nhập bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lê Thị Thảo, 39 years old, lives with her husband and two young children in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hóa province. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2008. Presently, in addition to raising animals and growing crops, her family makes extra money printing decorative images onto bamboo sleeping mats. The total income of the family is about 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to invest in buying pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Hiền  năm nay 27 tuổi. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ đầu năm  2008. Hiện tại công việc đem lại thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị là làm bánh đa, chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Bên cạnh đó chồng chị làm nghề thợ mộc nên hàng tháng gia đình chị cũng có thêm một khoản thu nhập rất ổn định. Với mức thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Hiền đang ngày càng ổn định hơn vì thế gia đình chị cũng ngày càng có điều kiện hơn để đầu tư cho các con ăn học
 Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm nguyên liệu phụcvụ cho việc sản xuất bánh đa của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Hiền, 27 years old, has participated in the TYM Fund since 2008. Presently, the main sources of income for the family are producing rice paper, raising animals, and growing crops. In addition, her husband does carpentry work, so that each month her family has another very reliable source of earnings. With their total income of 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month, the financial situation of Mrs. Hiền’s family is steadily becoming more stable, and she is able to invest more in her children’s education. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to buy more raw materials needed for producing rice paper.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Rice paper production

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hoàng Thị Chính  năm nay 32 tuổi, gia đình chị  có 2 con đang tuổi đến trường.  Hiện tại chị làm công việc chăn nuôi còn chồng chị đi buôn bán chiếu. Với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng  gia đình chị đang ngày càng có điều kiện hơn để đầu tư cho các con ăn học và cải thiện cuộc sống
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh daonh chiếu của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoàng Thị Chính is 32 years old. She has two children who attend school. At present, she works raising animals and her husband runs a business selling bamboo mats. With their total income of 3,000,000 VND (180 USD) per month, the family is gradually able to invest more in the children’s education and improve their standard of living. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to invest in the family’s bamboo mat business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bamboo mats

loans.name: Mr. Sar Phlang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank consists of twenty two members and is located in Chek village in Kandal province. They plan to use the loan they obtain for different purposes. Mr. S. P. is the bank president and was selected by the members. He and his wife, Mrs. Nhey Cham, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn for living.

They face an obstacle in the plantation because their field is infertile, which has a bad effect on their crop. In order to deal this problem, Mr. S. P. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the crop and make it more productive. He hopes to increase their incoM. and improve their living conditions with this loan. He is 49 years old and the father of five childrE.. Two of the childrE. are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Six members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay aN. principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments maN. months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on tiM.. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer to support the crop to make it more productive.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị N.  năm nay 47 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và  4 con tại huyện Quảng Xương tỉnh Thanh Hóa. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  2006. Hiện tại  nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi, nấu rượu và sự hỗ trợ của hai con đã đi làm với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lúa dự trữ phục vụ cho việc nấu rượu.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị N., 47 years old, lives with her husband and four children in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hóa province. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2006. At present, the main sources of income of the family are raising animals and making rice wine. Also, two of her children have gone to work and contribute to the total family income of about 2,000,000 VND (120 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to invest in buying more rice for their wine production business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice for making wine

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy pig food for pig breeding business

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Lê Thị Hương  năm nay 23 tuổi, chị đang sống cùng chồng và 1 con tại huyện Quảng Xương tỉnh Thanh Hóa. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  2007. Hiện tại  nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị là từ chăn nuôi, trồng trọt và lương công nhân của chồng  với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được  vay 5.000.000đ để đầu tư mua thêm lợn về chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lê Thị Hương, 23 years old, lives with her husband and one child in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hóa province. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2007. At present, the main sources of income of the family are raising animals, growing crops, and the wages from her husband’s job. Their total income is about 2,000,000 VND (120 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to invest in buying pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Kean

texts.en: Kean N. is a 46-year-old resident of the Kompong Tom province. He makes a living selling wood carvings from wood he has chopped from the forest himself, then he stores them in his home to sell. He is married to Im Phorn, age 51, a rice farmer who is a mother of seven children, five of whom are single and two of whom are married; two sons are employed as sellers of chopped wood and one daughter works in a garment factory. To help the farming business and alleviate hard physical labor, N. needs to request a loan of $500 for his wife to buy two buffalo to use for plowing the farmland. (Mr. N.'s wife is pictured because he was not available)

loans.use: To buy two buffalo to use for plowing farmland

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more rice to keep in stock then re-sell at better price.

loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Mrs. Oung S. is 28 years old and raises pigs to sell. She lives in Kampong Thom Province. She is married to Mr. Nut Phorn, a house roofing constructor in Phnom Penh City. Her husband has a lot of experience with this job and his work is recognized for its good quality. He moves to work depending on work requirements.

S. does not have any children and lives only with her husband. With her saved money, S. has so far built a part of a house but is not finished yet. Hence, she would like to request a loan to purchase wood to finish her house building.

loans.use: To purchase wood to finish her house building.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Kong Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people in Svay Chek village in Kampong Chhnang province form this village bank and Mrs. Sokha K. is the bank president. She is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and then resell later at a better price. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. She thus decided to ask for a loan to add to her capital and buy more rice for her current business.

Her husband, Mr. Sok Thouch, is a bicycle repairer. Mrs. Sokha K. is 42 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eight members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more rice to keep in stock and resell later at a better price.

loans.name: Mrs. Huoy Vann Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people in Ra village in Kampong Chhnang province formed this village bank and Mrs. Huoy V. is the bank president. She is a dry fish seller in the local market. Aside from this business, she is also a vegetable seller. Because the second business is going well, she wants to expand it and decided to purchase more vegetables to resell. Mrs. Huoy V. is a 52 year old widow with two children who are attending the local school. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Three members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetable to resell.

loans.name: Les

texts.en: Mr. Les S. is a farmer in Kro Sas Thmey village in Kampong Chhnang province. He owns one hectare of land on which he cultivates rice. He earns less income than he needs to provide a good life for his family. In order to improve his standard of living, he decided to request a loan to add to his savings. He will use the loan to buy a plot of land to cultivate rice and he hopes to increase his revenue in this way. His wife, Mrs. Nos Khor, is a chicken middleman. Mr. Les S. has two children who are enrolled in the local school. His wife is also presented in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land on which to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Nury

texts.en:
Nury M. lives in Khujand. She is married with three children. Nury trades in children's wear in the local bazaar, called Panjshanbe. She has worked with MicroInvest since 2008 and has shown herself to be an honest client. She has not had delays in her previous loan repayments so she is now taking a new larger loan.

Nury imports children's wear twice a month and has a good assortment. She is applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 1500 STJ for one month. She will use the loan to import seasonal wear from Kyrgyz Republic. Nury thanks Kiva for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To import seasonal wear to resell.

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Pheap T. lives in Tavak village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a housewife who is a good cook, preparing very delicious food for the family. Her husband, Mr. Meas Samorn, works in the Department of Rural Development and makes a small salary to support the family. He now wants to start a business to improve the family's living conditions.

Thus, Mrs. Pheap T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her saving and buy a rice mill to provide a service to the villagers. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. She is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the youngest one is a one year old.

loans.use: To buy rice mill to provide a service the villagers.

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano N. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2004. She first applied to MicroInvest when she decided to open a business selling food products. Rano started from a small-scale business but now she has a mini-market. She is an executive client so she takes a step-by-step loan procedure and increases the sum with each loan.

Rano has a good assortment in her market, trading in coffee, sweets, oil, preserved vegetables and more. Rano is now applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 4000 STJ over four months. She will use the loan to buy a refrigerator and to open a meat selling department. She plans to trade meat, sausages, salami and other items. She thanks Kiva and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and open a meat selling department in her market.

loans.name: Benie

texts.en:
Benie G. is a 32 year old mother of three children from Butuan City in Agusan Del Sur. She owns a store. She has been dreaming of a good life not only for her but also for her children. Her husband has been helping her in her business. Together, they have worked hard to support their children’s education.

She started her business using a small amount of capital that she had saved. She eventually bought assorted goods and sold them all to her neighbors. She never stopped dreaming until she joined CEVI and availed herself of its credit program. She needs a loan to purchase dry goods to sell in her store. She believes that by displaying more goods in her store she could earn more and compete well with other stores.

CEVI helps her sustain her business. She continually receives credit assistance, trainings, as well as insurance coverage, which she uses to flourish in her business.

loans.use: To purchase drygoods to add to her store.

loans.name: Tuty

texts.en:
Tuty P. lives in Khujabd. She is married with five children. She started her business twelve years ago but she traded in small wares firstly. In 2005 she heard about the MicroInvest loan procedure and applied. Tuty has now been a client of our microfinance program for three years. She is an executive and reliable client who has not had any delays in her loan repayment. She is now successfully taking the next step with an increased loan sum.

Tuty is engaged in a commercial service trading perfumery and children's wear. She has a good assortment that she brings from Istaravshan and Uzbekistan. Tuty is applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 800 STJ for three months to import new seasonal wears.

loans.use: To import a new seasonal assortment of wears.

loans.name: Sharaf

texts.en: Sharaf R. lives in the B. Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married with one child. She is engaged in a commercial service trading in household wares and perfumery. She works with the straight suppliers so she trades by low process. She is very polite and kind by nature and so has repeat customers who like her attention. Sharaf is now applying to Kiva for a business support loan of ten months to import new parcels.

loans.use: To import new parcels.

loans.name: Oum

texts.en:
Mrs. Oum P. makes and sells traditional Cambodian bamboo baskets with her husband in Kampong Thom Province, where she lives. She started the business in 2000 after having learned the craft from her parents, and now has a regular client base plus casual buyers in the market.

Her business is going well, but with a family of eight children, Oum would like to request a loan to purchase more bamboo to make additional baskets to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to make additional baskets.

loans.name: Nal

texts.en:
Nal V., 58 years old, resides in Kompong Tom Province where she makes a living braiding traditional Khmer clothes for sale. With her looms, Nal can make one to two sets of clothes per day, thereby earning a daily income of about $6 which helps to defray family living expenses. She is a good mother of five children and a dedicated wife to her blind husband. To help meet family expenses, two of Nal’s children are employed, one as a factory worker and another as a garment worker.

Because braiding is the family’s main source of income, Nal is now requesting a loan to buy additional braiding equipment. (She and her client appear in the picture of her workshop)

loans.use: To buy more braiding equipment.

loans.name: Neat

texts.en:
Mrs. Neat S., 47, is a rice farmer as well as selling beef soup and groceries from her house, while her husband is motorcycle taxi driver. Her business is going well; she sells to customers from her village. Many customers always come to eat her soup and tell her the soup is delicious.

Mrs. Neat S. has seven children, all of whom are single and live in the family's home. Her business is the one main source of income for the family so she needs to improve it. Hence, she would like to request a loan to purchase more grocery inventory to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery inventory to sell

loans.name: Soul

texts.en:
Mr. Soul M. lives in Tavak village in Kampong Chhnang province. He is a cow breeder. Since his cow-breeding business is going well, he wants to expand it; thus, he has decided to ask for a loan to buy two more cows for breeding. He hopes to increase his income after he sells his cows. His wife, Mrs. Phorn Phet, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.

Mr. Soul M. is 51 years old and the father of six children, one of whom is a chicken breeder while two others stay at home to do housework and help with their parents' business. The remaining three are attending the local school.

loans.use: to buy more two cows for breeding.

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Phann V., age 56, is a grocery seller who sells items such as ingredients for cooking at the local Prasat market. She currently lives in Kompong Tom Province. She is married with nine children, five of whom are single and four of whom are married. Two of her daughters are employed; one is a garment worker, and one helps with her mother's business.

Phann V.'s husband, Meung Peal, 53, is a palm climber. He has been doing his job for a long time, climbing palm trees to get palm juice and boiling it into palm sugar to sell, earning approximately US$ 4 each day. V. has requested a loan to buy more varied groceries for re-sale. She plans to use the rest for her daughter to decorate her house. (V.'s husband is pictured because she was not available.)

loans.use: To buy more varied sorts of groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Sieng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sieng N. is a farmer in Krang Leav village in Kampong Chhnang province. She owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. So Phat, is an assistant to the commune chief. Even though they try to work hard, they still barely earn enough income to support their family, and they still cannot provide better living conditions for their family.

Thus, Mrs. Sieng N. has decided to request a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her family. She is 35 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger one is too young to work or study because that child is only two years old.

loans.use: to add her savings to build a new house for her family

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more vegetables and fish for her business

loans.name: Ang

texts.en:
Mrs. Ang T., 33, sells pork as well as selling soup in the market, while her husband buys pigs for slaughter. Her husband, Mr. Sun Bunkhon, buys pigs from raisers for slaughter and Mrs. T. is responsible for selling the meat in the market. The business is going well but is still small.

Now, Mrs. Ang T. wants to expand the business to make it bigger and she needs to pay for authorisation. Hence, she would like to request a loan to pay for the authority permit and use any remainder as capital to purchase more pigs to slaughter to sell their meat. T.'s husband is pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: to pay for an authorisation and to purchase pigs for slaughter

loans.name: Saren's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Saren M. is the group leader for four members who all live in Tro Ngel village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a Khmer noodle seller and she also is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn her living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to hire laborers to work on the field. Thus, she has decided to ask for a loan to hire laborers to work in the field for the dry season. Her husband, Mr. Ton Saveth, is a policeman in the local district. Mrs. Saren M. is 47 and the mother of three children who are enrolled in the local school.

All the members in this village bank loan have end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to hire laborers to work in the field for the dry season

loans.name: Sopheach's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheach K. is the group leader for four people who all live in Choeung Khnar village in Kampong Chhnang province. She and her husband, Mr. Sen Sophal, are pig breeders. Since their pigs are getting bigger and bigger, they do not have enough money to feed them. Thus, Mrs. Sopheach K. decided to ask for a loan to add to her own money to purchase more pig feed for her pig-breeding business. She is 46 years old and the mother of three children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: to purchase more pig feed for her pig-breeding  business

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Oeurn Penh Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank which consists of thirteen members is located in Aleng village in Kampong Chhnang province, and they plan to use the loan which they obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Sam Oeurn P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a grocer. She owns a small store in her house and she now has a lot of customers so demand is high. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more good-quality groceries for her inventory. She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Phoeng Samnang, is a fried Chinese noodle seller. Mrs. Sam Oeurn P. is 36 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is a driver while the others are attending the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Eleven members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthly payment loans. The EoT-loan members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: to buy more good-quality groceries for her inventory

loans.name: Mann

texts.en: Mann C., 46, is a grocery seller who resides in Kompong Tom Province. She currently runs her business very well with a lot of regular customers to purchase her groceries, selling such items as canned foods, cakes, and especially cooked ingredients, since 1998. She has three children, all of whom are single; two of her daughters are employed as garment workers. Both currently receive salaries of US$ 120 per month. Her husband, Prac Vorn, 51, is a local chef for wedding parties or ceremonies. C. hopes to expand her business, but she lacks the money to do so, hence she would like to request funds to purchase an additional range of groceries for re-sale.

loans.use: To purchase additional groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Mr. Cheang Heng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people who live in Ra Village in Kampong Chhnang Province comprise this village bank loan led by Mr. Cheang H., the 47-year-old village bank president and father of seven children, two of whom are construction workers while the others are students in the local school. Cheang is a construction worker and his wife, Mrs. Hum Mean, is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which she cultivates rice and breeds pigs.

Hum wishes to expand the latter business as it is going especially well, so Cheang is requesting a loan to buy more piglets for her. This should result in increased family income and therefore a better life for the family.

This is a group loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Six members have monthly payment loans while 11 have end-of-term loan and. These latter members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans, AMK’s main product, are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor, allowing them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for his wife's business.

loans.name: Mrs. Leang Met Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Sixteen people who live in Ra village in Kampong Chhnang province form a village bank loan.  Mrs. Leang M. is the village bank president. 

She is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at better price.  Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it.  UnfortunateL., she does not have enough money to buy more rice.  In order to solve this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her capital to purchase more rice that she can then re-sell later.  She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her children. 

Her husband, Mr. Sum Tha, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  He also is a policeman who can make a small salary to support the famiL..  Mrs. Leang M. is 28-years-old and the mother of six children who are attending the local school.

This is a group loan consisting of mainL. end-of-term loans.  Three members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthL. payment loans.  These three members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term.  End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor.  It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financialL. able to.  Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term.  Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time.  AMK has a delinquency rate of onL. 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To add to her capital to purchase more rice that she can then re-sell later.

loans.name: Chres

texts.en:
Mr. Chres M. is a 63-year-old resident of Kompong Tom Province. He makes a living catching fish to sell in the market in and around Tunle Sap Lake, which currently earns him a revenue of around US$ 3 a day. He has been in this business since 1990. He has eight children; four are single and four are married. Two of his daughters are employed; one is a garment worker and another one is a national lottery agent; both are getting salaries of US$ 160 a month and also contribute to covering the family's living expenses.

Mr. Chres M.'s wife, Meas Pholly, 53, is a rice farmer. M. is asking for a loan to purchase a motorcycle for his daughters to ride to work. (M.'s wife appears in the picture, because M. was not available.)

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella E. is 36 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Stella sells drinks and foodstuffs. She also needs a generator to assist her when there is no electricity supply. She needs the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs and also a generator. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks, foodstuffs, provisions and a generator

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Pring Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank which consists of twelve members is located in Ra village in Kampong Chhnang province and they plan to use the loan which they have obtained for different purposes. Mrs. Mom P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn her living. Aside from the plantatiO., she is a cassava seller. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it; thus, she decided to ask for a loan to add to her capital to buy more cassava to re-sell. Mrs. Mom P. is a 36-year-old widow with three children who are attending the local school.

This is a group loan consisting partly of end-of-term loans. Five members have end-of-term loan and the rest of have monthly payment loans. The EoT members are not required to pay any principal O. the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments O. time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% O. Kiva.

loans.use: to add her capital to buy more cassava to re-sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to add to her savings to hire construction workers to build a new house

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more clay to make stoves

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna A. is a 44-year-old woman who lives in Achutti in the Bware sublocation of Rongo District. In 1981, she married a local school teacher; they now support 7 dependents, and 2 of them are in school.

Anna runs a tailoring and dressmaking business in Achutti Market. She has had this business since 2002; she started with her own savings and has improved the business with additional funds from K-MET. She purchases supplies in small quantities from nearby Migori and sells her sewing creations around locally and from her stall at the Achutti Market.

Anna is requesting a loan of 22,500 KSH (US$ 300) in order to buy more materials and sewing supplies. The profits from her business enable her to pay school fees for her children and pay household expenses, so she would like to expand and be able to make higher profits.

loans.use: To purchase dressmaking materials and supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Lang Khum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people who live in Kdey Thnot village in Kampong Chhnang province participate in the village bank loan and the members in this village bank will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Lang K. is a village bank president and is a stove maker in the local village. Since she now has a lot of customers, she decided to request a loan to buy clay and hay to make stoves in order to meet her customers’ demand. Her husband, Mr. H. Horn, is an ice-cream seller in the local village. Mrs. Lang K. is 48 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom helps in her stove-making business while the remaining four are attending the local school.

All the members' loans are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Bbuy clay and hay to make stoves

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add new items to her inventory.

loans.name: Sok Khim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Khim C. is a villager in Ta Sen village in Kampong Cham province. She is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and re-sell later at a better price. She wants to expand because all farmers are collecting the rice revenue during rice harvesting season. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more rice to keep in stock and re-sell later. She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family with this new loan.

Her husband, Mr. Leng Ean, has a motorbike taxi and can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sok Khim C. is 56 years old and the mother of a child who is a fruit seller in the market. Her husband is presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase more rice to keep in stock and re-sell later.

loans.name: Kea

texts.en: Mrs. Kea R., 24, is rice farmer as well as raising pigs, while her husband is lathe operator in Pursat town. She has one child who is a young teenager. Her pig raising business is going well and it is the one main source of family income. She can sell pigs for slaughter in three or four months. To increase her income, R. would like to request a loan to purchase more piglets to raise. R.'s husband is pictured because she was not available.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of underwear for a small business.

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im S. is 62 years old and a resident of Siem Reap Province. She runs a small laundry in her house to provide her services by washing clothes for her customers, for which she can receive $0.50 a set. She started the business in 1995. She is married to Soam Lo, 72, who also works with her. She has three children, all of whom are married and are employed: the eldest son is a soldier, the second son is construction worker, and the last son helps his mother to wash clothes. To make the family healthy, S. would like to apply for a loan to build a bathroom. The bathroom is a very important place for good hygiene.

loans.use: To build a bathroom

loans.name: Neang

texts.en: Mr. Neang C. lives in Ta Sen village in Kampong Cham province. He is a driver in a company. His wife, Mrs. Thorn Yun, is a housewife who is a good cook in the family. She now wants to operate a small restaurant in the local village; thus, she needs equipment such as tables, chairs, plates and so on. Mr. Neang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy them for his wife’s purpose. He hopes to increase the family income and provide a better life for his children. He is 48 years old and the father of three children who are enrolled in the local school. His wife is also shown with him in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to open a small restaurant in the local village.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of many items to replenish a small business.

loans.name: Lek

texts.en: Mr. Lek C. lives in Sduk Thom village in Kampong Cham province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. He earns little income, so he cannot provide a better life for his children. In order to deal with this problem, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a plot of land for growing rice to expand his rice revenue to support the household. His wife, Mrs. Hor Heang, is a pig breeder. Mr. Lek C. is 49 years old and the father of three children who are enrolled in the local school. His wife is also presented in the picture with him.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a plot of land for growing rice to expand rice revenue to support the household.

loans.name: Koeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Koeurn C. is a villager in Krodas Kor village in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Aside from this plantation, she is a duck breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to purchase more ducks for her current breeding business. Mrs. Koeurn C. is a 31-year-old widow with two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To request a loan to purchase more ducks for her current breeding business.

loans.name: Sakoy

texts.en: Mr. Sakoy K. lives in Vield village in Kampong Cham province. He is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Hay Heng, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces some problems because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Sakoy K. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and he would use the rest of the loan to buy more fertilizers, fuel for a pump, and hire laborers to work in the field. He is 28 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizers, fuel for a pump, and hire laborers

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sorn S., 39, raises pigs to sell, and lives in Pursat Province. She can sell the pigs for slaughter in four or five months. Her husband is employed as a driver from Phnom Penh. She has four children, all of whom live in the family home. To increase the income for the family, S. would like to request a loan to purchase more piglets to raise and she would use the remaining money to purchase groceries for sale.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets to raise and purchase groceries for sale

loans.name: Savaing

texts.en: Mr. Savaing M. lives in Ta Sen village in Kampong Cham province. He is a motorbike taxi driver who can make a small income to support the family. His wife, Mrs. Khat Eng, is a pig breeder. Since her pigs are bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to support them. Thus, Mr. Savaing M. decided to request a loan to purchase pig food and he would use the rest of money to buy more piglets for breeding. He hopes to increase his income and improve the living conditions with this loan after he sells his pigs. He is 54 years old and the father of six children, one of whom is a construction worker while another is a teacher in the local school. One stays at home to do housework while the others are enrolled in the local school. His wife is also presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To request a loan to purchase pig food and use the rest of money to buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: Mrs. Nan O. is a farmer in Vield village in Kampong Cham province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. She faces some problems in the plantatiO. because she does not have enough money for cultivating. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizer, petrol for pumping, and hire laborers to work in the field. Her husband, Mr. Heang Pour, is a fisherman who can catch a little fish to support the family. Mrs. Nan O. is 36 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. Her husband is also presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: To request a loan to buy rice seeds, fertilizer, petrol for pumping, and hire laborers to work in the field.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa B. is divorced and has 7 dependents. She has received no formal education. Adwoa sells food items like sugar, beans, maize, and gari. She also cooks food for sale at Abrobeano near Elmina, which she has done since 2002. Adwoa uses her income to pay for her children's school fees, utility bills and other family expense.

Adwoa will use the loan as additional capital to buy more foodstuff for sale; she also wants to increase her preparation of food for sale. With new profits from her expanded business, Adwoa plans to support her children's education.

loans.use: Adwoa will use the loan to purchase more foodstuff for sale and increase her preparation of food for sale.

loans.name: Than

texts.en: Than S. is a widow who lives in Siem Reap Province. She is 48 years old and makes a living washing clothes as well as selling roast beef in an area of her village. She started both businesses twenty years ago and currently earns revenue of approximately $10 per day. S. is a sacrificing women and works hard to earn the money to sustain her kid's food. She now has four children, all of them single. One her son is a motorcycle taxi driver, earning an income around $5 a day to help meet the family's needs. S. needs to ask for a loan to purchase beef and ingredients to make roast beef for resale and a motorcycle for her family to ride.

loans.use: To purchase beef with ingredients to make roast beef

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther A. is married and has 5 dependants. She has received no formal education. Esther sells food items like beans, maize, and gari at Abrobeano near Elmina, which she has done since 2007. Her husband is a trader. Esther uses her income to assist her husband in meeting the family's financial needs. Esther will use the loan to use as additional capital to buy more foodstuff for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to support her children's education.

loans.use: Esther will use the loan as additional capital to buy more foodstuff for resale.

loans.name: Mrs. Run Heang Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Run H. is the village bank president of eight people who live in Pou Steang village in Kampong Cham province. She sells prohok, which is maked from small fish and is usually used in soup. Since this business is going well, she now wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more prohok for her business in order to meet her customers’ demand. Her husband, Mr. Dam Deang, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Run H. has five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Mrs. Sokhny C. did not come to take the loan but her husband did, so he is presented in the picture instead of his wife.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Two members have end-of-term loan and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more prohok to re-sell.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen C. is grocery seller who lives in Pursat Province. She is widow with six children, one of whom is married. She has been selling since 2000 and her business is going well. She sells a variety of products to her customers such as cakes, Khmer wine, meat, and vegetables, etc. To expand her business by purchasing more groceries, she would like to request a loan.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing more groceries

loans.name: Chet

texts.en: Mr. Chet C. is a villager in Krodas Khor village in Kampong Cham province. He is a palm juice collector who gathers it to process into palm sugar and wine. His wife, Mrs. Choeun Yuth, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she faces a small problem because her field has infertile soil which affects her crop. In order to solve this problem, Mr. Chet C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field to make his crop more productive. He is 28 years old and the father of two children who are attending the local school. His wife is also presented with him in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the field to make his crop more productive.

loans.name: Reth

texts.en:
Mr. Reth V. is a villager in Troeng village in Kampong Cham province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice. He is 45 years old and the father of six children, two of whom are employed in garment factory. The other children attend the local school. 

His wife, Mrs. Hoer Thorn, is a duck breeder. Since her ducks are growing bigger and bigger, she does not have enough money to support them. Mr. Reth V. has decided to ask for a loan to purchase duck food for his wife's breeding business. His wife is presented on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To purchase duck food for his wife's breeding business

loans.name: Abayaa

texts.en:
Abayaa Z. produces palm kernel oil and sells it at Asem near Abura. 

Abayaa has received no formal education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Abayaa has been producing palm kernel oil for sale since 1998. She is responsible for assisting her husband in meeting the financial needs of the family. 

She will use her loan to buy more palm fruit, so she can produce more oil to sell to her customers, who demand more than she produces. She hopes to use the new profits to reinvest in her business, increasing her capital base and enabling her to increase production.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruit

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Mrs. Seng Y is a farmer in Kvet village in Kampong Cham province. She owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. 

She now faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil. Thus, she has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer to make her crops more productive. Her husband, Mr. Im Koeun, is a fisherman who can gather a little fish to support the household. 

Mrs. Seng Y is 38 years old and the mother of a child who is attending the local school. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Kep

texts.en:
Mrs. Kep M., 28, is rice farmer. Her husband is bricklayer. She has two teenage children who are in school. Mrs. M. and her husband work hard every day to support their family. 

Because rice farming is the main source of income for the family, Mrs. M. would like to request a loan to purchase two young oxen to use for farming.

loans.use: To purchase two young oxen to use for farming

loans.name: Farhod

texts.ru:
Фарход парень 28 лет женат , имеет 3 детей.Проживает в отдалёном кишлаке Хамровод, Гафуровском районе.
С малых лет он помогал отцу по уходу за скотом.Теперь став самостоятельным семьянином он ведёт свой бизнес по откорму и  продаже крупного скота.Он на сегодня имеет две большие коровы и 5 баранов. Фарход обратился в Микроинвест чтоб увеличить свой скот. Он рад кредитоваться в дальнейшем и продолжать свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Farhod is a 28-year-old guy, who is married with three children. He lives in a remote village of Hamrovod, Gafurov. From an early age Farhod helped his father to care for the cattle. Now, an independent family man, his business is the fattening and sale of large-horned cattle. At present he has two large cows and five rams. Farhod has applied for a loan with MicroInvest in order to increase his herd, investing in the future to continue his business.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Mrs. Yen Y. lives in Kvet village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband, Mr. Ny Norn, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. 

Mrs. Yen Y. does not have a cart to transport the rice. Since it is now the season for harvesting rice, she is requesting a loan to buy a cart. She will use the cart, pulled by two cows, to transport rice from the field to her house. 

She is 48 years old and the mother of three children. One of her children is employed in garment factory, another is a pig breeder, and the youngest one is a farmer. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cart to transport rice

loans.name: Anatoliy

texts.en:
Anatoliy is not married. He lives with his mother. He has a car repair business. He has been in this business for 15 years. He likes cars and likes fixing them. His average income is 5,000 UAH per month. 

Anatoliy is a hard-working and very responsible person. The clients value his skills as well as his honesty. Thus, he has many repeat clients. 

Anatoliy needs to purchase a piece of equipment for his shop.  He would like to get a loan of 7,500 UAH. It will allow him to offer more services to his clients and to develop his business.

loans.use: To purchase equipment

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
Memunatu S. sells fish. She buys fish from the fishermen, brings them home for processing and preservation, and then sends them to the market at Abura to sell. 

Memunatu has received no formal education. She is married and has 11 dependents. Her husband is a farmer. Memunatu has been selling fish for about 20 years. She is responsible for helping her husband to pay for their children's school fees, utility bills and family expenses, because her husband's income is too small to meet the needs of the family. 

Her loan will be used to buy fish in larger quantities for processing and sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in the expansion of her fish trade.

loans.use: To buy fish in larger quantities

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa A. is forty-five years old. She is a married woman with six children. Four of her children are independent. They have completed college and are gainfully employed. 

Currently, she lives with her husband and their two youngest children, who are now in the basic school, in Atebubu. Atebubu is a town in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Atebubu is a farming community. The inhabitants produce food crops like maize, yams, millet, and beans. 

Hawah says she enjoys trading and has been in the trading business for three years. She owns a small grocery kiosk in her community and also trades in items such as beans, maize and millet. Hawah distributes her goods to "pito" sellers in her community. Pito is a local drink produced from milled millet with a colour similar to Coca-Cola. She says that she took over this business from her late mother and, through this business, has helped her husband take good care of the family. 

Hawah wants a loan to expand her business to purchase more goods. She is in a group called "Do Good." The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and support each other to repay.

loans.use: To purchase more maize, beans, millet and grocery products.

loans.name: Fatia

texts.en:
Fatia A., age forty-five, is a married woman with two children who are currently in high school. Fatia lives with her family in Atebubu in Ghana. Atebubu is a town in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Atebubu is a farming community. The inhabitants produce food crops like maize, yams, millet, and beans. 

To support her family, Fatia runs a small grocery kiosk in her neighbourhood. She also sells food items, such as macaroni and tomatoes, on a table in front of her kiosk. She has been in this business for fifteen years. 

Fatia buys her goods from the farmers in the community and treks to the markets in nearby towns to sell them. She says that she also supplies her products to food vendors in her community. 

Fatia wants more working capital to meet the cash demands of her business. She wants to buy the goods in bulk to save her from having to make frequent trips to the city. She hopes to build up savings to provide her kids with a very good education and a brighter future. 

Fatia is in a community group called “Do Good.” The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and support one another to repay.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Najeeb

texts.en:
Najeeb lives in the 16th district in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married, has three children and is 40 years old. He is responsible for his family. For many years, he has been selling tires. He would love to see his business be more successful. He has a good number of clients and he wants to expand his business, so he needs a loan.

He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for 12 months to complete his stock and buy new tires for his shop. This will help his business and his family. He is sure that, after a brief period of time, he will have a good tire business.

Najeeb is very happy with this loan process. He wants to thank those that help with this process. He hopes to continue his partnership with AFSG and Kiva. He would like to thank all lenders around the world.

loans.use: To buy new tires for his shop

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru: Солиева Малика заёмщица в возросте 39 лет по специальности врач в городской поликлинике Костакоза.Она имеет 3 детей , муж водитель маршрутного такси.Малика очень любит ухаживать за скотом.Каждые три месяца Малика с мужем выводит скот на рынок и продав подороже сразу покупают подешевле.Вот так они и продолжают свой бизнес по откорму скота.Малика подала заявку на 1600 сомони чтоб купить две коровы , т.к. сейчас скот дешевле чем в другие месяца.
texts.en:
The borrower, Malika S., is 39 years old and a doctor at the Kostakoz town medical center. She has three children, and her husband drives a commercial passenger van. Malika really loves caring for cattle. Continuing in their business of fattening cattle, every three months, she and her husband put their cattle up for sale, and immediately afterwards purchase more at a cheaper rate. Malika has applied for a loan of $475 (1600 somoni) in order to buy cattle, which are cheaper now than at other times of the year.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia Nkansah is fifty years old and is married with eight children. The last born is in the high school, but the older children have all completed school and are now independent. 

Cecilia lives with her husband and the last child in Atebubu, a town in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. It is a farming community. The inhabitants produce food crops like maize, yams, millet, and beans. She is a hardworking woman and, through her hard work, has helped her husband to give their children a good education. 

Cecilia bakes bread. She buys her baking ingredients – flour, margarine, and sugar -- from the city, where they are readily available. She bakes and distributes to beverage sellers and other bread sellers in her community at wholesale prices. She has been in business for three years. 

Cecilia wants to use the loan to expand her business by buying materials in bulk so that she can distribute to a larger number of customers. 

Cecilia belongs to the “Do Good” community Trust Bank group. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and peer support to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bread-baking materials in bulk

loans.name: Muharrama

texts.en:
B. Muharrama is 28 years old and is not married. For the past three years, she has been selling vegetables, such as potatoes, onions, and carrots. This business is the economic base that supports her family and generates their savings. 

Muharrama’s working day usually begins early in the morning at 8:00 a.m. She is a teacher by profession. Currently, she teaches at the school until the afternoon, and then goes to market to run her business. Muharrama is planning to increase her working capital, because, in new year, she will have a lot of clients. 

She is requesting 2000 Somoni ($ 600 USD). The loan will be repaid in 9 months. Your support will really help her. Muharrama is counting on your help. Be an important part of Muharrama’s business.

loans.use: To Increase the range of vegetables that she sells

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte C. sells food, like beans and maize, in Elmina. Charlotte has received no formal education.  She is married and has 1 child. Her husband is a fisherman. 

Charlotte has been selling food since 1991. She is responsible for helping her husband to pay their children's school fees, utility bills, and family expenses, because her husband's income is too small to meet the needs of the family. Her loan will be used to buy more food to meet her customers' increasing demand. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to invest in a building project she is embarking on with her husband for the family.

In the picture, is she in her warehouse where she keeps the bags of maize, beans, and other foods for distribution. On the floor are the empty food sacks. She was out of stock when the picture was taken.

loans.use: To buy more food to meet her customers' increasing demand.

loans.name: Haja Conteh Group

texts.en:
This is Haja C. and Fatmata K.. They named their group "Believe In God."  They are local entrepreneurs in Makeni in northern Sierra Leone. This is not their first loan from Kiva through SMT. They have received several loans from Kiva through SMT. Previously, each group member received a loan of Le 600,000.00. That loan created meaningful changes in the lives of these borrowers. They were able to use the proceeds to pay for their children’s school fees, and to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans. 

Again, they are requesting a loan of Le 600,000 each to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Haja (on the left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-eight years of age. She was born in BatK., which is about thirty-six miles from Makeni. She is married to a photographer and they have six children. Two of her children are in secondary school, two are in primary school, one is in nursery school, and the last is not yet of school age. She has been a businesswoman for over twenty years.
 
Haja sells articles like toothpaste, Vaseline, jewelry, fingernail polish, and baby powder. With this new loan, she will expand her business. She will buy at least a carton of toothpaste, a carton of Vaseline, a carton of powder and dozens of earrings. She usually travels to Freetown, where she buys the items that she sells. The fare to Freetown is Le 12,000. In Freetown, a carton of toothpaste costs at least Le 200,000, and it costs Le 150,000 for a carton of Vaseline and Le 150,000 for a carton of powder.

So far, Haja faces no serious challenge in her business that are worth noting. Business is going fine and well. She enjoys what she does for a living. With the increase in profit that Haja will make as a result of the loan, she will be saving to buy a plot of land to build a house in the future.

loans.use: To expand her business by buying more articles

loans.name: Rabinatu

texts.en:
Rabinatu A. is thirty-five years old. She is a wife and the mother of three children who are all still in the basic school. Rabinatu lives with her nuclear family in Atebubu, a town in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. 

Rahinatu has been trading since she was a teenager and she enjoys trading very much. She started with her mother even when she was in elementary school. She is, therefore, very experienced and is now running her own business. Rabinatu says that she has been in business for twenty years. 

She sells fresh groundnuts, groundnut paste, groundnut oil, and many other products from groundnuts. She buys the groundnuts from the farmers in the surrounding villages where it is cost-effective. She supplies the groundnut paste and the oil to the local food vendors in her community. 

Rahinatu wants a loan to buy groundnuts in bulk to meet the demand of her customers, which increase daily. Rabinatu is a member the  “Do Good” community trust bank group. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and provide peer support to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts in bulk.

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.en:
O. Mavjuda is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of 3 children. Mavjuda's lack of a stable job and the slow productivity of her husband's business as an independent constructor didn't leave enough money to pay the expenses of the family. 

This was the reason that Mavjuda decided to start her own business 18 years ago. She sells the fabric used to make their national dresses. Little by little, she has made her business grow and, by allowing her clients to pay in installments, her orders are getting bigger. Now her business is running normally. However, she would like to continue improving herself (and her business) so her situation will be stable in the future. 

She is asking for a loan of 3800 Somoni ($1125 USD) that she will pay back in 9 months. With this money, Mavjuda will be able to buy seasonal fabrics for the national dresses. The power to help her business grow is in your hands. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seasonal fabrics

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence Debek is 38 years old. She is a wife and the mother of five children. Two of her children have completed senior high school, and the rest are in junior and primary schools. She is a local manufacturer of palm kernel oil. 

Palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel, which is a by-product of palm oil. The palm kernel is processed through various stages to obtain the palm kernel oil, which is used to prepare many local dishes, like fried fish and pastries. Selling palm kernel oil is one of the most common occupations of local women in the town of Goaso. 

Florence produces and supplies her oil to food vendors to prepare their meals. However, her production is on a small scale, because she does not have enough working capital to support wholesale production. 

With this loan, she wants to buy a hundred bags of palm kernel and an electric milling machine to reduce the drudgery of manual effort. She believes the loan will help her to raise more income to provide food for her family and to finance her children’s education. 

She belongs to the ‘God’s Love’ community trust group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and provide support to one another to repay.

loans.use: To buy a hundred bags of palm kernel and an electric milling machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing fertilizer, etc. for his tree farm

loans.name: Shafoat

texts.ru: Шафоат женщина в возросте 37 лет имеет 4 детей.Сама работает учительницей в средней школе.Преподаёт начальные классы.Она со старшим сыном занимается откормом скота ,поэтому она в сезон хочет увеличить свой скот .Сейчас у неё три коровы.Взяв займ она хочет купить баранов.Она благодарна за поддержку инвесторов в первую очередь KIVA
texts.en:
Shafoat is a 37 year old woman with 4 children. She works as a school teacher at an elementary school. With help of her older son, she also keeps livestock. During this season, she would like to purchase a few more animals. Currently, she has 3 cows. Using this loan she wants to buy 3 sheep. She thanks KIVA and all of the investors for their help.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: cattle

loans.name: Zauyara

texts.en:
Zauyara is thirty-five years old. She is married and the mother of three children. Two of her children are in elementary school; the last-born is still breastfeeding. With the help of the government's free compulsory basic education, many mothers have sent their children to school to learn about their future careers. 

She lives in Ejura, a farming community in the Ashanti region, with her family. Ejura has a mix of all tribes of people, such as the Ashanties, northerners, and the rest. 

She sells "gume," which is a type of brown rice that is used most often to prepare what we called "waakye" (a mixture of rice, beans, tomatoes, and spices). Waakye is enjoyed with stew or shito by many Ghanaians, because of the aroma and the taste. Gume is just an ordinary rice, but it has a different taste and color. Zauyara buys her rice directly from the farmers to avoid middlemen. 

Zauyara has been in this business for the past twenty years, and has lots of marketing experience. She inherited this business from her mother, whom she worked with during her childhood. 

Zauyara wants a loan to buy more gume to supply her customers, who travel from very far places to purchase it. She believes the loan would help her to support to her children's education better and to revive her business. 

She is member of the “Trust in God” trust group. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days. and her picture was taken during her group meeting. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy gume (brown rice) in bulk

loans.name: Manija

texts.en:
S. Manija is 36 years old. She is married and the mother of three adorable children. Manija has a grocery store that she attends to herself, in additon to caring for her family and her home. She began her small business five years ago with financial support from her husband, who is a mechanic. She started her business to increase her large family’s income, and the business has been gradually growing ever since. 

In order to expand her business, she requests a loan of 2500 Somoni ($750 USD). Manija is planning to spend the loan to buy more goods to sell, thus increasing the range of her goods. She promises to repay her loan within 8 months and thanks everybody who has decided to support her. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

loans.use: To buy goods to sell

loans.name: Zamira

texts.ru: Замира женщина 37 лет мать 3 детей,работает в поликлинике медсестрой.Сейчас у неё одна корова , которая в день даёт 7 литров молока. Узнав что на рынке сейчас скот подешевел, она хочет взяв кредит купить ещё корову.Когда она на работе ей помогает по уходу за скотом её старший сын.Она благодарит за понимание всех инвесторов Микроинвест.
texts.en:
Zamira is a 37 year old woman with 3 children. She works as a nurse. Currently, she owns one cow that provides her with 7 quarts of milk every day. When she found out that the prices for livestock dropped, she decided to take out a loan to purchase one more cow. When she is at work, her older son helps her take care of the livestock. She thanks all Kiva investors for understanding and their help.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
He is a young and dynamic individual who is motivated to improve his life so that the future can be brighter for his household. 

Ibrahim I. is twenty-nine years old. He is married with a child who is still breastfeeding. He operates a clothing shop in Atebubu, a town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana, where most people farm crops, such as maize, beans, millet, and yams. 

Ibrahim realized that the people in his community travel to the big city of Kumasi to buy clothing, such as jeans and  shirts. He seized that as an opportunity to look for customers. Ibrahim treks to the city of Kumasi to purchase clothes from wholesalers at a moderate price, and retails them directly to customers in Atebubu. 

Ibrahim wants a loan to buy clothing, like jeans, shoes, and men's shirts. He believes this will help him to expand his business. He aspires to send his child to the university, and believes this can be possible through the loan. 

Ibrahim is a member of ‘The Living God’ trust group. They guarantee each another to access the loan and act as social collateral to repay the loan on time. His picture was taken during their group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more clothing

loans.name: Trisula

texts.en:
Mrs. Trisula S., 38, lives in Khapichhen. Khapichhen is located in Lalitpur district and most of the people in this region are engaged in small businesses. Mrs. S. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and one son. Her husband, Mr. Gokarna S., works in a cyber-cafe. Her son is now six years old and he is attending pre-primary school.

Mrs. Trisula S. is engaged in weaving woollen sweaters and shawls. She started weaving 6 years ago. She also opened a woollen sweater shop near her house. She weaves different types of woollen sweaters. She sells sweaters to big dealers. Especially foreigners love hand-knitted woollen sweaters. Nowadays the demand for woollen sweaters is increasing. So, to meet the demand, Mrs. S. is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs. 20,000 to buy wool and implements for making woollen sweaters.

loans.use: To buy wool and implements for making woollen sweaters

loans.name: Karima

texts.en:
Karima A. is fifty years old, married and the father of five children. Presently all the kids are schooling. Karima lives at Atebubu in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana with his family. Atebubu is a community you would like to stay in because of its serene atmosphere and the unity that exists among the people in the community.

Atebubu is a farming area and the common thing that can found there apart from the food crops they cultivate, is the use of bicycles. Interestingly, almost everyone owns a bicycle; they ride it to their farm, school, etc. Karima is a professional bicycle repairer, and not only that, but he also sells bicycle parts. Karima has been in this business for the past 10 years. Through it, he obtains his daily income to support his family.

He travels to Kumasi which is a nearby town to purchase his bicycle parts. He wants this loan to buy more bicycle parts to restock his inventory to avoid daily trips. And he needs to have more parts to serve his customers. With the loan he believes he can have more resources to provide quality education for his kids. He is a member of a community group ‘The living God’ whose members guarantee for one another to access the loan and as social collateral to repay the loan. Karima would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy more bicycle parts for servicing bicycles

loans.name: Rachana

texts.en:
Mrs. Rachana S., 29, lives in a nuclear family with her husband, Mr. Ramesh S., and one daughter in Khapichhen, Lalitpur. Her husband works in a medical shop and her daughter is now just 11 months old.

Mrs. S. makes different types of woollen sweaters. She took 2 months' training for this work. She sells woollen sweaters to sweater dealers. Mostly, foreigners love hand-made woollen sweaters. So nowadays, the demand for these sweaters is constantly increasing and she is very busy weaving sweaters.

Mrs. S. is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs15,000 to buy different varieties of wool for weaving different woollen sweaters. She wants to save her earnings to provide a good education for her daughter because in Nepal the cost of education is very high.

loans.use: To buy wool to knit woollen sweaters for sale

loans.name: Agartha

texts.en:
Agartha M., 44, is married with four children; two have successfully completed senior high school and the other two are still in junior high school. Agartha runs her business in Atebubu, a farming community where she lives with her family. She counts herself among the blessed ones because there are few people like her who sell used clothes in the area where she lives.

M. has been selling used clothes for the past twenty years now, and it is from this business that she obtains her source of living. She has very good customer relations which allows her to sell very fast among her competitors in the marketplace of Atebubu. Used clothes are purchased by the economically active poor since brand new ones are expensive.

Agartha wants the loan to buy an increased supply of used clothes. She treks to the surrounding villages during their market days to sell them dresses. Agartha believes in one thing: she is convinced that her market share can increase within a month when she secures the loan. She is a member of a group called ‘The living God’ Trust Group. Members agree to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan. She does not sell on group meeting days and her picture was taken during her group meeting. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: to buy bales of used clothes

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua D. is the mother of four children. She turned fifty last month and she lives with her husband and the children at Atebubu in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. The major occupation of the people is farming through which they derive their daily income to care for their families.
