La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de lotería y su pulpería en la que vende los productos como: gaseosa, pan, sopas, refrescos naturales y golosinas, la ubicación de su negocio es en el reparto Carlos Fonseca en chichigalpa, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 1 año y so otro negocio que es la venta de lotería es de 28 años, Don Bonifacio inicia con otro tipo de negocio como lo fue la venta de lotería mas tarde debido a las circunstancias que presento nace otro negocio y este fue iniciado por su esposa quien era la poseía el negocio ya que anteriormente ella trabaja en el mercado central de chichigalpa y debido a la difícil situación Don Bonifacio decide reactivar el negocio de la pulpería que anteriormente administraba su esposa por lo que este negocio es el que le proporciona la fuente de ingresos necesarias para el y su familia, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que este será utilizado para extender el inventario de la pulpería y proporcionar mayor oferta en esta época navideña que se acerca para la compra de: gaseosa, pollo y golosinas.
texts.en:
Bonifacio Martínez is 53 years old and is accompanied. Mr. Bonifacio has 2 children. His older son is 18 years old and is in his fourth year of secondary school. His other son is 16 years old and is in his third year of secondary school. His partner works as a housewife. Her goals are to strengthen his business since he has two businesses; he sells lottery tickets and has a small grocery store. He wants his business to remain active. He dreams of improving his home because his business is located in the house. He also wants to improve the quality of the products he offers his clients.

He sells lottery tickets and has a small grocery store where he sells products like soda, bread, soup, natural beverages, and sweets. His business is located in the area of Carlos Fonseca in Chichigalpa. He has had the business for one year. He has been selling lottery tickets for 28 years. Mr. Bonifacio began with another type of business which was selling lottery tickets and later started another business because of certain circumstances. His wife was the owner of the grocery business because,earlier, she worked in the central market in Chichigalpa. As a result of a difficult situation, Bonifacio decided to restart the small grocery store business that his wife managed before because this business provides them with a source of necessary income for him and his family. This loan will be used as capital for his work. It will be used to increase the inventory in his small grocery store and provide a better supply for Christmastime, which is approaching. He will buy soda, chicken, and sweets.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for his business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Afosatu

texts.en:
Married with four children who are currently in school, 55-year-old Afosatu M. has produced palm oil, derived from palm nuts, the fruit of the palm tree, for 10 years. She supplies the oil to food vendors to prepare their meals. The driving force behind her hard work is the commitment to providing quality education to her children so that they can enjoy better life opportunities than she did when she was young. 

Afosatu is now requesting a loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine to enable her to produce larger quantities of oil. She believes this will help her expand her business, thereby raising more income to support her husband’s efforts in providing the children with quality education. She belongs to a community group called “Gyese wo bre” (meaning, unless you work hard) Trust Group, whose members support and guarantee each other’s loans.

loans.use: To buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
La señora Nancy es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor de Canela” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 25 años de edad, es casada y tiene 2 hijos menores de edad que mantiene económicamente. 
Es la primera oportunidad en que recibirá un préstamo, además nos cuenta que se dedica a la venta de prendas de vestir y además tiene a su cargo un wawawasi.
Con este préstamo de S/. 500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará prendas de vestir para vender en las fiestas de navidad.
Nancy desea continuar trabajando para aumentar sus ganancias y satisfacer las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nancy is a member of the Lovely Flower (Flor de Canela) Community Bank in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 25 years old, is married, and has 2 young children, who she supports economically. This is the first time that she will receive a loan. She sells clothing and is in charge of a wawawasi (day-care center for children). With this loan of 500 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy clothing to sell at Christmas parties. Nancy wants to continue working to increase her earning and meet the needs of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy clothing

loans.name: Flora Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Flora es casada, tiene 3 hijos, uno de 16, otro de 13 años y un pequeñito, los que todavia estan bajo su cuido. Doña Flora junto a su marido tienen dos negocios, que son la venta de ropa usada y algunas mesas de billar. El crédito lo está solicitando para la compra de productos y fortalecer el negocio de los billares, su marido quien le ayuda a atender el negocio de los billares, mientras ella se encarga de la administración de la venta de la ropa usada; con las ganancias del negocio pagan los gastos familiares y costos de mantenimiento del local donde tienen el salon de billares.  Doña Flora se ha caracterizado por ser una persona responsable, desea crecer en su negocio para que a sus hijos no les falte lo necesario.
texts.en:
Mrs. Flora is married and has 3 children. One is 16, another is 13, and the other is very young. The children are still under her care. Flora, along with her husband, has two businesses. One is selling used clothes and the other is a billiard hall. She is requesting this loan to buy products and to strengthen her billiard business. She counts on the support of her husband who helps her take care of the business while she manages the business of selling used clothes. With the earnings from the business, they pay for the family expenses and the costs of maintaining the billiards hall. Mrs. Flora characterizes herself as a responsible person. She wants to grow her business so that her children do not lack what they need.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Billiards hall

loans.name: Jesus Antonieta

texts.es:
La señora Jesús es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 61 años de edad, es soltera y madre de 2 hijos mayores de edad. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/. 300 compró insumos para su negocio de pensión familiar para estudiantes. Tiene casi 5 años trabajando con el banco comunal, además nos cuenta que con el tiempo le gustaría diversificar su negocio.
Con este préstamo de S/. 400, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas comprará más insumos para atender a sus clientes estudiantes en las próximas fiestas de navidad.
Jesús desea seguir trabajando para aumentar las ganancias de su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Jesús is a member of the Women United in Triumph (Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo) Community Bank in the province and department of Puno. She is 61 years old, is single, and is the mother of 2 adult children. With her first loan of 300 soles, she bought supplies for her student meal plan business. She has been working with the Community Bank for almost 5 years. With time, she would like to diversify her business. With this loan of 400 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy more supplies to attend to her student clients during the upcoming Christmas festivities. Jesús wants to continue working to increase her earnings from her business.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy supplies to take care of her student clients

loans.name: Félicité

texts.fr: Dame  N. Félicité est née le 11 juillet 1975, mariée au sieur TADOGBE Joseph, elle est mère de deux enfants, Irène et Luc, tous scolarisés. Elle achetait du mais, de l'haricot au marché DANTOKPA, qu'elle revenait vendre devant son domicile à avotrou. Elle a décidé de rompre avec le marché dantokpa et d'aller elle meme s'approvisionner dans les campagnes auprès des cultivateurs, pour ce fait qu'elle a sollicité un pret.
texts.en:
Ms. Félicité N. was born July 11, 1975, is married to Mr. Joseph Tadogbe, and is a mother of two, Irène and Luc, who both attend school. She used to buy corn and beans in the Dantokpa market, which she sold from her home in Avotrou. She decided to part ways with the Dantokpa market and to go stock up on her own in the fields from the farmers, which is why she is seeking this loan.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 bags of corn and 2 drums of oil

loans.name: Birame

texts.fr: Birame travaille dans l'assurance depuis une dizaine d'année. Ce  marié et pére de 3 enfants entretient sa famille grâce aux revenus tirés de son activité. Il sollicite ce crédit pour renforcer son activté.
texts.en:
Birame has been working in the insurance business for approximately ten years. He's married and the father of three children, and he provides for his family thanks to the revenues of his business. He's seeking this loan to bolster his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster his insurance business

loans.name: Jossie Ada

texts.es:
La señorita Jossie es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 21 años de edad, es soltera y espera un hijo. 
Con el primer préstamo de S/.300 compró abarrotes para venderlos en su puesto de trabajo en el mercado central. Tiene casi 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.
Con este préstamo de S/.700, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más abarrotes para ofrecerlos en su puesto de trabajo en el mercado central.
Jossie desea continuar trabajando para mantener a su hijo que viene en camino.
texts.en:
Jossie is a member of the “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 21 years old, single, and pregnant. With the first loan for S/.300 she bought groceries to sell in her stand in the central market. She has been working with the communal bank for almost 2 years. With this loan for S/.700, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more groceries to sell in her stand in the central market. Jossie wishes to continue working to support her child who will soon be born.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries to sell in her stand in the market

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam I. is a married woman with two children.  She is forty-eight years old.  One of her children has completed college and the other has yet to complete.  Mariam and her family are currently living in Atebubu, a farming community in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. 

Mariam sells cereals such as beans, maize, and groundnuts.  She has been selling for fourteen years.  She buys the cereals from the farmers in her locality.  Mariam says prices are quite moderate when buying from the farmers directly and, in this way, she is able to make a good profit.  She sells her goods to the local food vendors. 

Mariam is in a group called ‘Assurance’ Trust Bank in her community.  The members in the group guarantee one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy more cereals and grains.

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La señora Luz es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia  y el departamento de Puno. Tiene 61 años de edad, es conviviente y madre de 3 hijos de los cuales 2 están aún bajo su responsabilidad. 
Con su primer préstamo que recibió de S/.300 compró papa para venderla. Nos cuenta que primero se dedicó a la venta de papa y posteriormente cambió de rubro para dedicarse a la venta de prendas de vestir. Tiene 6 años trabajando con el banco comunal.
Con este préstamo de S/.700, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más prendas de vestir para vender en las fiestas de navidad.
Luz desea seguir trabajando para aumentar sus ganancias y continuar apoyando a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Luz is a member of the “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 61 years old, married, and mother of 3 children, 2 of whom are still under her responsibility. With the first loan for S/.300 she bought potatoes to sell. She tells that that at first she sold potatoes, but then changed profession to selling clothing. She has been working with the communal bank for 6 years. With this loan for S/.700, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more clothing to sell in the Christmas holidays. Luz wishes to continue working to increase her earning and continue supporting her children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing.

loans.name: Darling De Los Angeles

texts.es: Darling es una joven madre que tiene un niño de 4 años de edad, cuenta con el apoyo de su marido que trabaja en Costa Rica y le envia dinero para los gastos familiares; Darling tiene una pequeña pulperia, y solicita a AFODENIC credito para comprar productos de su  pulperia y asi fortalecer el inventario, pues con las pequeñas ganancias que obtiene puede darle mejores condiciones a su pequeño hijo.
texts.en:
Darling is a young mother who has a 4 year old son. She relies on her husband’s support, and he works in Costa Rica and sends money for the household expenses. Darling has a small convenience store and asked for a loan from AFODENIC to buy products for her store and thereby increase her inventory. With the small profits she obtains she can provide better living conditions for her small son.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products to sell in her store

loans.name: Viviana Elsa

texts.es:
La señora Viviana es socia del Banco Comunal “Víctor Echave” distrito, provincia  y departamento de Puno. Tiene 43 años de edad, es soltera y madre de 2 hijos estudiantes a los que mantiene económicamente. 

Con su primer préstamo de S/.300 compró materiales para confeccionar artesanías y compró artesanías para vender en su puesto de trabajo. Nos cuenta que vive en casa de sus padres junto con 6 personas de su familia.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,200, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más mercadería para vender en su puesto de artesanías.

Viviana desea seguir trabajando para apoyar a sus hijos y que lleguen a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Viviana is a member of the “Víctor Echave” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 43 years old, single, and mother of two school-aged children who she supports economically. With the first loan for S/.300 she materials to make artisan products and she bought artisan products to sell in her stand. She tells us that she lives in her parents’ home along with 6 people from her family. With this loan for S/.1,200, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more merchandise to sell in her artisan stand. Viviana wishes to continue working in order to support her children so that they may become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy artisan products

loans.name: Felicitas

texts.es:
La señora Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento D. Puno. Tiene 79 años D. edad, es viuda y madre D. 6 hijos y actualmente vive con una hija. 

Con el primer préstamo D. S/.500 aumentó su capital D. trabajo y compró verduras para su puesto D. trabajo. Tiene un año trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que hace 18 años adquirió su puesto D. trabajo por un traspaso D. una comadre.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 800, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará verduras que más se venden en las fiestas D. navidad, año nuevo y reyes, ello lo realizará en su puesto D. trabajo.

Felicitas desea continuar trabajando para apoyar en su hogar y a la hija que vive con ella.
texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of the “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 79 years old, widowed, and mother of 6 children. Today she lives with one of her daughters. With the first loan for S/.500 she increased her working capital and bought vegetables to sell in her stand. She has been working with the communal bank for a year and tells us that 18 years ago she acquired a stand from a friend. With this loan for S/.800, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy vegetables that are commonly sold during the Christmas, New Year, and Epiphany holidays to sell in her vegetable stand. Felicitas wishes to continue working in order to support her home and the daughter with whom she lives.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vegetables

loans.name: Abel

texts.es:
EL Señor de nombre Abel F. O. tiene la edad de 64 años, su estado civil es casado por lo que tiene 3 hijos de los cuales ninguno depende de el ya que trabajan por cuenta propia, su esposa labora de conserje en la universidad de león, sus propósitos son de seguir luchando por su negocio ya que hay muchos negocios como estos pero son pocos los que pueden permanecer tanto tiempo en este ámbito, sus deseos son que su esposa deje trabajar ya que a su edad es un trabajo muy cansado, además de este propósito esta obtener un futuro mejor para ir superando su porvenir.

Su actividad económica es la de pulpería en la que vende productos como: granos básicos, pan, refrescos, golosinas y jabones, la ubicación de su negocio es en su casa de habitación de la texaco Guido ½ al sur, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 18 años, Don Abel inicia con otro tipo de negocio que trabajaba en mecánico de aviación  y decide establecer su negocio con una caja de jabón, aceite y golosinas por lo que consigue la afluencia de clientes y empieza por la compra de un estante y al paso del tiempo decide comprar vitrinas para colocar ropa y otras cosas, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de mas producto y así reforzar su venta.
texts.en:
Mr. Abel F. O. is 64 years old, married, and has 3 grown, independent children. His wife works as a custodian at León university. His goals are to continue fighting for his business as there are many businesses like his but few that can survive for so long in these times. His wishes are that his wife can leave her job because at her age the work is very tiring. In addition he would like to secure a better future in order to continue improving his future. He has a convenience store where he sells items such as: basic grains, bread, refreshments, snacks and soap. His store is located in his house, ½ Guido south of the Texaco station. He has had this business for 18 years. Don Abel began with another type of business, working as an aviation mechanic, and he decided to open his business with a case of soap, oil and snacks as this is what his customers wanted. So he began by buying a stand and over time he decided to buy showcases to display clothing and other items. This loan is for working capital to buy more products and in this way support his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to buy items for his store

loans.name: Moah

texts.en:
Moah B. is a thirty year old married woman.  She has three children who are still in the basic school.  She lives with her family in Atebubu. 

Moah works very hard to help her husband take care of the family.  She is a farmer as well as a trader.  She sells yams and other food items.  Moah says she buys from the northern part of the country where prices of food stuffs are cost effective.  She then sells to the food vendors and other consumers in her locality.  

Moah wants to increase her working capital so that she can buy yams in bulk.  She wants the loan to help her achieve this dream. 

Moah is in a group called “God is King” Trust Bank in her community.  The group members guarantee one another as collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk.

loans.name: Karolina

texts.es: Karolina, casada,  de 23 años de edad, tiene un hijo de 3 años, solicita su 2do credito para realizarle mejoras a un pequeño cuarto que construyó en un terreno que le dio la Alcaldia. Ella trabaja como domestica, cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo que trabaja como lavador de vehiculos en un taller de autolavado. Karolina y su esposo han ido ahorrando y ya tienen comprado algunos materiales para la mejora que va a realizar, como es el techo de su humilde vivienda. El mayor de Karolina es poder construir poco a poco su vivienda con las condiciones necesarias para su pequeño hijo.
texts.en:
Karolina is married, 23 years old, and has a three year old son. She is seeking her 2nd loan in order to make improvements to a small room that she built on a plot of land the village gave her. She works as a domestic employee, and depends on the support of her husband who works as a washer in a car wash. Karolina and her husband have been saving and now they have bought some materials to make the improvements, such as the roof of their humble home. Karolina’s primary goal is to be able to, little by little, construct their home in order to provide adequate shelter for their small son.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair the roof of her home.

loans.name: Miriam

texts.es:
La señora Miriam es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 34 años de edad, es conviviente y madre de 3 hijos menores de edad que mantiene económicamente. Tiene casi un año y medio trabajando en el banco comunal.
Con su primer préstamo que recibió de S/.300 compró prendas de vestir para iniciar su negocio. Nos cuenta que trabaja en un café de la ciudad de Puno.
Con el préstamo de S/.600, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más prendas de vestir para aumentar el ingreso de su negocio.
Miriam desea continuar trabajando para satisfacer las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Miriam is a member of the “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 34 years old, married, and mother of 3 young children for whom she supports economically. She has been working with the communal bank for a year and a half. With the first loan for S/.300 she bought clothing items to start her business. She tells us that she works in a café in Puno city. With this loan for S/.600, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more clothing items in order to increase the income from her business. Miriam wishes to continue working in order to support her family’s needs.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing.

loans.name: Margarita Gloria

texts.es:
La Señora de nombre Margarita Gloria Rubí tiene la edad de 57 años, su estado civil es soltera Doña Margarita tiene 3 hijos de los cuales tienen la edad de 34 años el mayor, su otro hijo tiene la edad de 30 años y su otra hija de 28 años ninguno de sus hijos dependen de ella todos trabajan por cuenta propia, sus deseos para su negocio son  mantenerlo estable ya que no en el actualmente la situación que el país atraviesa actualmente se hace mas difícil de obtener un trabajo, sus propósitos son de proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda ya que es lo mas importante además desea pintarla para que esta pueda conservarse bonita y le dure mucho tiempo.


Su actividad económica es la venta de tiste y frijoles el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 5 años, la ubicación del negocio es en su casa de habitación, sus inicios se dan por cuenta propia y decide establecer un negocio de una pulpería la que no obtuvo mucha afluencia de clientes pero lo que poco que consigue de este negocio le da la posibilidad de establecer otro negocio que seria la venta de frijoles y la venta de tiste y así obtiene la afluencia de clientes ya que ambos productos le proporcionan ingresos para su familia, es por eso el motivo de su financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para compra de productos como maíz, canela y cacao para realizarlas en el mercado la estación ya que le resulta mas favorable realizar aquí y al por mayor.
texts.en:
Mrs. Margarita Gloria Rubí is 57 years old and is single. Mrs. Margarita has 3 children. The oldest is 34 years old, her other son is 30 years old and her other daughter is 28 years old. None of her children depend on her; all of them work for themselves. She wants to keep her business stable since, at present, the situation that the country is going through makes it more difficult to find a job. Her goals are to make improvements on her home, which is very important. She also wants to paint her house so that she can keep it beautiful and it can last for a long time.

She sells tiste (a corn and cocoa drink) and beans. She has owned this business for 5 years. The business is located in her house. She decided to start a small grocery store on her own, but didn’t have many clients. From that business, however, she gained the possibility to establish another business, where she would sell beans and tiste. In this way, she earned many clients; both products supplied her with income for her family. As a result, she is requesting this loan for capital for her business. The capital will be used to buy products like corn, cinnamon, and cocoa to make her products in the market since she achieves more favorable results there and at wholesale.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital for her business

loans.name: Hashmud

texts.en:
Hashmud B. is thirty-seven years old.  He is married and has given birth to two children.  Both of his children are currently in the basic school.  Hashmud and his family live at Atebubu.  Atebubu is a town that has most of its inhabitants actively involved in the farming business. 

Very few are into different trades such as batik and tie-dye production and Hashmud is one of those few.  Batik and tie-dye is a local textile design in which raffia or waxes are used to resist the pigment (dyes) from getting to undesired areas.  

Hashmud buys materials such as mercerized cotton, caustic soda, etc from the city.  He has been in this business for six years.  He sells in the local market and treks to surrounding villages. 

Hashmud wants a loan to buy more of the raw materials so that he can produce on a large scale to be able to trek to more markets.

loans.use: To buy tie-dyeing materials.

loans.name: Nely

texts.es:
La señora Nely es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 31 años de edad, es soltera y no tiene hijos. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/.500, compró repuestos de electrodomésticos para vender en su tienda. Nos cuenta que está preparando la apertura de una nueva tienda en su domicilio y que tiene casi 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal. 
Con este préstamo de S/.1,200, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más repuestos de electrodomésticos y terminará su nueva tienda.
Nely desea continuar trabajando para aumentar las ganancias de su negocio.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nely is a member of the Women United in Triumph (Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo) Community Bank in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 31 years old, is single, and doesn’t have any children. With her first loan of 500 soles, she bought spare parts for electrical household appliances to sell in her store. She tells us that she is preparing to open a new store in her home. She has been working with the Community Bank for almost 2 years. With this loan of 1,200 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy more spare parts for electrical household appliances and will finish her new store. Nely wants to continue working to increase her earnings from her business.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy spare parts for electrical household appliances and will finish her new store

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses K. A. is thirty-five years old.  Moses is a father of two children who are currently in the basic school.  He lives in a rented apartment with his family in a town in the Brong Ahafo region called Atebubu. 

Moses loves trading a lot.  He sells food items such as maize, rice, yams, etc in the market square in his community.  He says that he also distributes to some food vendors and restaurant operators.  He has been in business for six years.  Moses says he buys his stocks from the farmers in his community and those in nearby towns. 

He wants a loan to buy the stocks in bulk so that he can distribute to more customers. 

Moses is in a group called “Ami” (translated as Amen) in his community.  The group members guarantee one another as collateral to be able to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy cereals and other foodstuffs in bulk.

loans.name: Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo denominado Nueva Esperanza se conformó en el mes de setiembre del año 2.007.
El origen de la asociación del comité se dio a partir de la motivación de un grupo de amigas, preocupadas por contribuir con la mejoría de la calidad de vida.
Las integrantes del grupo se dedican a distintas actividades comerciales como: venta de frutas, mercería, ropas, comidas, bijouterie, leche, Cds., y a la confección de ropas.
El comité cuenta con una comisión sólida, es un excelente grupo el cual activa continuamente para la recaudación de fondos para solventar alguna eventualidad, se destaca la solidaridad y la comprensión entre ellas.
 Las actividades que desarrollan cada una son:

Eleuteria C.	Venta de mercería
Aparicia R.	Venta de frutas
Catalina R.	Venta de mercería
Nilda F.	Venta de bijouterie
Martina C.	Venta de ropas
Cristina G.	Venta de comidas
Petronila B.	Venta de ropas
María Lourdes C.	Venta de ropas
Leonora Martínez	Venta de mercería
Lilian P.	Venta de ropas
Dionicia Giménez	Venta de leche
Marina R.	Venta de frutas
Alicia Sánchez	Venta de frutas
Blanca Velázquez	Confección de ropas
Artemia C.	Venta de Cds
texts.en:
The group called Nueva Esperanza (New Hope) was formed in September 2007. The group was started as a result of the motivation of a group of friends, who were concerned about contributed to improving their quality of life. The members of the groups pursue different commercial activities like selling fruit, haberdashery, clothes, food, jewelry, milk, and CDs and making clothes. The group has a solid commission. This is an excellent group which is continually active in collecting funds to pay for some possibility cost. This emphasizes the solidarity and understanding among the women.

They each pursue the following activities: Eleuteria C. sells haberdashery Aparicia R. sells fruit Catalina R. sells haberdashery Nilda F. sells jewelry Martina C. sells clothes Cristina G. sells food Petronila B. sells clothes María Lourdes C. sells clothes Leonora Martínez sells haberdashery Lilian P. sells clothes Dionicia Giménez sells milk Marina R. sells fruit Alicia Sánchez sells fruit Blanca Velázquez makes clothes Artemia C. sells CDs

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The members of the group will invest in the purchase of milk; sugar; fruit; clothes; items for the home like pots, jars, cutlery, etc.; CDs. All of these items will then be sold. They will also buy thread and fabric for the production of clothes, among other things.

loans.name: Justa Mariluz

texts.es:
La señora Justa es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo”, del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 27 años de edad, es soltera y actualmente vive con su hermana y una sobrina. 

Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/. 300 compró papas y cereales para vender en su puesto de trabajo. Tiene 3 años trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que hace 4 años adquirió un puesto por un traspaso de su madre.

Con este préstamo de S/.1,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará papas y cereales para vender en  fiestas de navidad.

Justa desea continuar trabajando para aumentar sus ganancias e independizarse.
texts.en:
Mrs. Justa is a member of the Women United in Triumph (Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo) Community Bank in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 27 years old, is single, and, at present, lives with her sister and a niece.

With her first loan of 300 soles, she bought potatoes and cereals to sell in her stand. She has been working with the Community Bank for 3 years. She acquired the stand 4 years ago through a transfer from her mother.

With this loan of 1000 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will buy potatoes and cereals to sell during the Christmas festivities.

Justa wants to continue working to increase her earnings and independence.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy potatoes and cereals

loans.name: Teófila Esperanza

texts.es:
La señora Teófila es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor de Canela”, del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 36 años de edad, es casada y madre de 4 hijos menores de edad a quienes mantiene económicamente. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/.300, compró productos para mejorar su restaurante. Tiene casi 4 años trabajando con el banco comunal.
Con este préstamo de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, mejorará su restaurante realizando arreglos a su local.
Teófila desea continuar trabajando para cubrir las necesidades de su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Teófila is a member of Lovely Flower (Flor de Canela) Community Bank in the district, province, and department of Puno. She is 36 years old, is married, and is the mother of 4 young children, who she supports economically. With her first loan of 300 soles, she bought products to improve her restaurant. She has been working with the Community Bank for almost 4 years. With this loan of 1500 soles, which will be repaid in 4 installments, she will improve her restaurant by making repairs to her location. Teófila wants to continue working to meet the necessities of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will make repairs on her restaurant

loans.name: Mila

texts.es:
La señora Mila es socia del Banco Comunal “Flor de Canela” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 43 años de edad, es soltera y madre de 2 hijos que son estudiantes y dependen de ella. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/.300, compró prendas de vestir para venderlas en su puesto de trabajo.
Con este préstamo de S/.500, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más prendas de vestir para aumentar sus ganancias al venderlas.
Mila desea continuar trabajando para apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios y que lleguen a ser profesionales.
texts.en:
Mila is a member of the “Flor de Canela” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 43 years old, single, and mother of 2 school-aged children who are dependent upon her. With the first loan for S/.300 she bought clothing items to sell in her stand. With this loan for S/.500, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more clothing items in order to increase her income from her sales. Mila wishes to continue working in order to support her children in their studies with the hope that they become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothing.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel M. is the name of this client.  He is thirty three years of age, married and a father with two children.  He comes from a clan called ‘Asona’ family.  

This family has a parrot for their symbol.  In the olden old days, they believed that the parrot was a wise bird who could communicate with them when something unfortunate was about to happen.  The bird would reveal the secret things to them. For that reason, anyone who belongs to this family is proud about that.  

Emmanuel is a carpenter who has been manufacturing any form of room decor for twelve years now with lots of experience.  He says to give your specifications and it will be done.  Some of the things he does are beds, wardrobes, kitchen cabinets, etc.  Emmanuel says that, of late, it is becoming a bit difficult to fund his business due to inadequate supplies of wood for further processing. 

Emmanuel wants the loan to buy wood because that has been his major challenge.  He believes the loan will help him to meet the needs of his customers.  As creative as he is, he also has the hope that this will enable him to expand his business and save towards his children's education. 

He is a member of a group called ‘Holiness’ Trust group.  Members agree to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy nails, saw, wood, glue and sand paper etc.

loans.name: Lydie

texts.fr: Lydie S. est diplômée de l'école hôteliére de Dakar. Depuis 2 ans elle a préféré ouvrir ses propres affaires dans le domaine de la restauration et la vente des boissons alcoolisées. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son commerce en cette veille de fête de fin d'année.
texts.en:
Lydie S. has a diploma from the Hotel School of Dakar. Two years ago, she decided to open her own business in the sector of food serving and sale of alcoholic beverages. She's seeking this loan to bolster her business on the eve of the end-of-year festivities.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her business

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La señora Francisca es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 67 años de edad, es soltera y tiene a su cargo a sus sobrinas y a una tía. 

Con el primer préstamo que recibió de S/.300 aumentó su capital y compró verduras para venderlas en su puesto de trabajo. Tiene casi 4 años trabajando con el banco comunal y nos cuenta que se dedica desde hace 55 años a la comercialización verduras.

Con este préstamo de S/.2,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará verduras para vender en las fiestas de navidad, además de pagar compromisos adquiridos.

La señora Francisca desea continuar trabajando para seguir apoyando a su familia.
texts.en:
Francisca is a member of the “Mujeres Unidas al Triunfo” Communal Bank located in the district, province and state of Puno. She is 67 years old, single, and she takes care of two nieces and an aunt. With the first loan for S/.300 she increased her capital and bought vegetables to sell in her stand. She has been working with the communal bank for almost 4 years and she tells us that she has been selling vegetables for 55 years. With this loan for S/.2,000, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy vegetables to sell in the Christmas holidays and in addition pay some debts she has. Francisca wishes to continue working in order to continue supporting her family.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy vegetables

loans.name: Sodelba

texts.es: Sodelba es pequeña comerciante que se dedica a la elaboracion de productos lacteos para comercio local, lo que le brinda el sustento familiar y sacar adelante a sus hijos, diariamente muy temprano acopia la leche la que luego procesa en queso y cuajadas, los fines de semana venda fritanga a estudiantes de la UNAN; en la actualidad tiene un hijo en la universidad contando este unicamente con el apoyo de su mamá, su mayor sueño es que su hijo se dradue de medico, para locual necesita financiamiento para reforzar su pequeño negocio y alcanzar su meta de preparar a su hijo que sera en el futuro el encargado de su sustento.
texts.en:
Sodelba is a small businesswoman who makes milk products to sell locally, thus providing support for her family and her children’s future. Very early every day she gathers the milk which she will later process into cheese and cheese curds. On the weekends she sells fried food to the students at UNAN. Today she has a son in the university depending only on his mother’s support. Her biggest dream is that her son becomes a doctor, for which she needs financing to support her small business and meet her goals of preparing her son who will be, in the future, responsible for support.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sell milk products

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Married with four children who are currently in school, Vida, 37, supports her husband in providing for the household through the sale of used clothing. She lives in Atebubu in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana, a farming community consisting largely of peasant farmers both young and old. 

The market for used clothing in Ghana is substantial because brand new clothes are too expensive for many people.  In this business for the past 22 years, Vida makes her sales by ‘hawking,’ which consists of going from one market center to another with her wares. She is now requesting a loan to buy more bales of used clothes to increase her inventory, and believes the loan will help her save for her children’s future and eventually rent a store to trade from. 

Vida belongs to the Holiness Trust Group, whose members agree to support and guarantee each other’s loans.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothes.

loans.name: Andrea Benedicta

texts.es:
La señora Andrea es socia del Banco Comunal “Víctor Echave” del distrito, provincia y departamento de Puno. Tiene 72 años de edad, es casada y madre de 9 hijos mayores edad. 
Con el primer préstamo que recibió, aumentó su capital de inversión para comprar frutas y golosinas para venderlos en su puesto de trabajo. 
Con este préstamo de S/.3,000, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará más golosinas y frutas para venderlos en su puesto de trabajo en el puerto.
Andrea desea continuar trabajando para aumentar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Andrea is a partner with the Victor Echave Community Bank of the district and province of Puno. She is 72 years old, married and has 9 grown children. With the first loan that she received she increased her investment capital by buying fruits and sweets to sell at her job. With this loan of $975, which will be repaid in 4 payments, she will buy more sweets and fruits to sell. Andrea wants to keep working in order to increase her earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fruits and sweets

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.es: La  Sra. O. habita junto a su familia en su casa ubicada en el barrio Tamanes de Juigalpa, local donde tambien tiene su cocina artesanal y su mostrador donde diariamente muy temprano palmea sus tortillas, las que su clientela compuesta por sus vecinos llega a comprarle su producto a tempranas horas durante los 3 tiempos de comida; sus hijos 2 mayores y 1 pequeño que asiste al colegio de primaria, el marido se desempeña como conductor de taxi y le apoya con los gastos del hogar; su mayor anhelo es algun dia contar con un horno electrico que le permita evitar el calentamiento en el fogon artezanal que actualmente ocupa.
texts.en:
Mrs. O. lives with her family in their home that is located in the Tamanes de Juigalpa neighborhood. This is also where she has her kitchen and sales counter where every day she gets up early to make tortillas. Her customers, mostly people from the neighborhood, arrive early to buy her tortillas for each of the three meals of the day. She has three children, 2 older children and 1 younger child that goes to elementary school. Her husband is a taxi driver and helps with the household expenses. Her greatest desire is to one day have an electric oven that would allow her to avoid heating up the artisans oven that she has now.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Selling tortillas

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: Doña Ana Maria, es soltera y con 2 hijos pequeños, tiene un pequeño negocio consistente en elaboracion de cajetas de lecho, coco y caramelos para venta a pulperias al por mayor, diariamente muy temprano alista a sus 2 hijos para enviarlos a la escuela para luego emprender su trabajo para la elaboracion de sus productos y hacer las entregas a sus clinetnes, solicita apoyo financiero paa incrementar su capacidad y poder atender a mayor clientela y asi realizar su sueño de algun dia ver convertidos en profesionales a sus pequeños.
texts.en:
Ana Maria is single and has two small children. She has a small business making milk caramels, coconut candies and caramels that she sells wholesale to grocery stores. Every day she wakes up early to send her 2 children to school and then she starts her job of making her candies and delivering them to her customers. She is seeking financial support in order to increase her client base and her production. One day she hopes to see her dream come true--to see her children become career professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Making and selling of caramels

loans.name: Laura Del Carmen

texts.es: La Sr. Laura tiene 33 años de edad, habitante del barrio Villa Venezuela de la capital de Managua, estado civil soltera, tiene dos preciosos hijos de 4 y 10 años de edad ambos estudian, los planes para su pequeña familia es ofrecerle un patrimonio y un mejor nivel de vida, comprar un vehiculo para trasportar a sus hijos. Doña Laura tiene su negocio de variedades en donde vende productos de belleza, ropa, zapatos y otros, trabaja en ese ramo de venta desde hace 4 años, lo inicio con fondos propios y sus planes a corto plazo para su negocio es ampliarlo creando otras tiendas en la región de Managua y convertirla un una micro empresa. Gracias a los préstamos de Afodenic lograr comprar mayor cantidad de productos como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas, camisolas, zapatos, cosméticos y perfumes, generando mayores utilidades.
texts.en:
Laura is 33 years old, lives in the neighbourhood of Villa Venezuela of the capital Managua. She is single and has 2 gorgeous children aged 4 and 10 who are both in school. Her goal for her little family is to be able to leave them an inheritance and a better quality of life, and buy a car to transport her children. Laura has owned her business for 4 years: she sells beauty products, clothing, shoes and other items; she opened her business with her own savings and her short-term plans for her business are to expand it by creating other stores in and around Managua and turn the business into a microenterprise. Thanks to the loans from Afodenic she will be able to buy merchandise in greater quantities: pants, blouses, shirts, camisoles, shoes, cosmetics and perfumes, generating greater profits.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of clothing for children and adults

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase shoes as well as natural medicines for a small business.

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.es:
El Comité denominado Oñondivepa se conformó por la iniciativa emprendedora de la actual secretaria María Clotilde A., la misma había contactado con la asesora del programa para conformar el grupo. Se iniciaron en el mes de abril del 2.008.
Actualmente el comité está conformado por 17 integrantes las cuales se dedican a diversas actividades comerciales y cada una de ellas ha invertido el préstamo en: compra de gallinas ya que la zona en la cual se encuentra localizado el grupo la población se dedica en exclusiva a la venta de gallinas y huevos, compra de accesorios para la elaboración de bijouterie, compra de yerba mate, bebidas, cosméticos, mercería, etc.

El detalle de actividades por señora es como sigue:
1	Aurelia Báez	Venta de gallinas
2	Eliodora G.	Despensa 
3	María Estela M.	Venta de carbón
4	Graciela M.	Venta de huevos
5	Mirian M.	Despensa 
6	Diana C.	Venta de gallinas
7	María Clotilde A.	Venta de gallinas
8	María Del RosarioA.	Venta de gallinas
9	María Stela P.	Venta de remedios refrescantes
10	Hermelinda L.	Venta de gallinas y productos de limpieza
11	Gladis Ruíz Díaz	Venta de bebidas
12	Elodia M.	Venta de gallinas
13	Martha B.	Venta de gallinas
14	María Cristina A.	Venta de bijouterie
15	Alba C.	Venta de mercería
16	Marcelina Fernández	Venta de mercería
17	Modesta E.	Venta de gallinas

Los fondos serán invertidos en: compra leche, azúcar,  yerba mate, cosméticos, gallinas ya que la mayoría de las integrantes se dedican a la venta de gallinas, compra de accesorios para la elaboración bijouterie como canutillos, etc., compra de mercería, artículos básicos para el hogar para su posterior venta como: yerba mate, azúcar, carne, panificados, bebidas, etc..-
texts.en:
The Oñondivepa Committee was put together thanks to the entrepreneurial initiative of Maria Clotilde A., who is now the group's secretary. Maria Clotilde got in touch with one of Fundación Paraguaya's loan officer in order to put together the group, which began in April 2008.

The Oñodivepa Committee currently has 17 member, who are involved in a variety of commercial activities and will use their loans for different purposes.

Here is a list of the group members and their businesses:
1 Aurelia Báez, Chicken sales
2 Eliodora G., Grocery store
3 María Estela M., Charcoal sales
4 Graciela M., Egg sales
5 Mirian M., Grocery store
6 Diana C., Chicken sales
7 María Clotilde A., Chicken sales
8 María Del RosarioA., Chicken sales
9 María Stela P., Medicinal drinks sales
10 Hermelinda L., Sales of chickens and cleaning products
11 Gladis Ruíz Díaz Venta de bebidas
12 Elodia M., Chicken sales
13 Martha B., Chicken sales
14 María Cristina A., Jewelry sales
15 Alba C., Hardware sales
16 Marcelina Fernández, Hardware sales
17 Modesta E., Chicken sales

The group members will use their loans to buy: milk, sugar, yerba mate, cosmetics, chickens (since the community where the group lives is made up primarily of chicken farmers, who subsist on chicken and egg sales), beads for jewelry-making, hardware items, and other basic household items which will be bought and resold (like meat, bread and drinks).


Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy milk, sugar, yerba mate, cosmetics, chickens, beads for jewelry-making, hardware items and basic household goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase ingredients to keep producing food.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza is a member of the Retoño (“Sprout”) Village Bank.  Esperanza is 39 years old and is the single mother of one child.  

Esperanza lives in a rental property in the Los Artesanos neighborhood.  She travels to different regional markets to buy grains and cheeses, which she then sells in bulk to market vendors in Ayacucho.  Sometimes, she also works as a street vendor and sells her wares directly to the public.  Esperanza also knits custom-ordered sweaters.  

Esperanza needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy grains.  She dreams of building her own home and of providing her son with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Esperanza es socia del Banco Comunal Retoño. 
Esperanza es madre soltera, tiene 39 años y 1 hijo, Esperanza vive en una casa alquilada en el barrio de Los Artesanos, Esperanza viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde compra cereales, quesos, que luego los comercializa por mayor a los comerciantes de los mercados, y en algunas oportunidades lo vende directamente de manera ambulatoria. Además Esperanza teje chompas variadas que realiza según pedido. 
Esperanza necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cereales. 
Esperanza sueña con construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a su hijo.

loans.use: Buy grains in regional markets

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of cloth and materials to sew clothes.

loans.name: Luchadores Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes del g/s LUCHADORES Viven en un barrio llamado el Raizon  ubicado en el Km. 21 carretera Masaya – Managua, sus negocios lo tienen en su casa de habitación ya que ofertan a todo el barrio sus productos. 
Doña Jessenia Aliso es la coordinadora del G/S, este grupo esta participando en su primer ciclo  comenzó vendiendo frutas y golosinas  un canasto en  la puerta de su casa, teniendo necesidad de hacer crecer su negocio busco a Don Ernesto y Don Guadalupe para formar el grupo, cuando recibió su crédito lo invirtió en la compra de mercaderías varias y ahora cuenta con una mini pulpería, la que administra y a la vez cuida de su familia.
Ella sueña en un futuro de mejorar su vivienda para tener mejores condiciones de vida, para esto cuenta con el apoyo de ADIM.
Don Ernesto vende cosméticos por encargos el ya cuenta con una clientela fija la que por dos años ha abastecido con estos productos.
Don Guadalupe cuenta con el apoyo de su esposa, por lo tanto, su pulpería es más grande y tiene más experiencia, aplico a un préstamo en ADIM por buenas referencias de una vecina.
texts.en:
The members of the Luchadores Village Bank live in the El Raizon neighborhood, on kilometer 21 on the highway from Masaya to Managua. All of their businesses are located in their homes, and their offer their products to the whole neighborhood. Doña Jessenia Aliso es the group's coordinator. This group is currently beginning its first loan cycle. Doña Jessenia started out selling fruits and sweets from the door of her home, then sought out Don Ernesto and Don Guadalupe to put together the Village Bank so that she could expand her business. When she received her loan, she bought different items to sell, and now she runs a small general store. She administers the store and takes care of her family at the same time. Her dream is to improve her house in order to have a better quality of life; this is why ADIM is supporting her.

Don Ernesto sells cosmetics from a catalog, and already has regular clients, since he has been selling these products for the past two years.

Don Guadalupe's wife helps him financially, so his general store is larger and he has more experience in this field. He decided to apply for a loan from ADIM because of a neighbor's recommendation.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital; to offer more products to clients

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To add new clothing to her stock.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is a member of the Retoño (“Sprout”) Village Bank.  She is 36 years old and separated with two children.  

Antonia lives in a rental property.  She travels to different regional markets to sell dry goods, wool and bread.  On the days when there are no markets, Antonia spins yarn from animal wool and sells her yarn in the market by the kilo.  

Antonia needs a loan of 800 soles to buy rice and sugar.  Antonia dreams of building her own home and for her children to complete their education. 

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Antonia es socia del Banco Comunal Retoño. 
Antonia es separada, tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Antonia vive en casa alquilada, Antonia viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde vende abarrotes, lanas, panes. En los demás días Antonia hace hilados de lana de animales que luego vende en los mercados por kilos. 
Antonia necesita un préstamo de 800 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar. 
Antonia sueña con construir su casa y que sus hijos culminen sus estudios.

loans.use: Buy rice and sugar

loans.name: Maria Luz

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Kusikuy Village Bank.  “Kusikuy” means “Be Happy” in Quechua.  Maria is 34 years old and married with three children.  

She has a beauty salon in her home where she works seven days a week.  She hires an assistant during especially busy times of the year.  She also sells cosmetics and accessories.  Maria needs a loan of 1050 soles to buy hair dye and a glass display counter.  Maria dreams of expanding her business, of outfitting her salon with all the necessary equipment and of educating her children.
 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Maria Es socia del Banco Comunal Kusikuy que significa Alégrate en quechua. 
Maria  es casada, tiene 34 años y 3 hijos, Maria tiene un salón de belleza en su domicilio, actividad que realiza todos los días y en épocas de alta demanda tiene una ayudante, también vende algunos accesorios, cosméticos. 
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de tintes y para comprar una vitrina. 
Maria sueña con que su negocio se amplíe, implementar con todo lo necesario su taller y educar a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy hair dye and a glass display counter

loans.name: Jeny

texts.en:
Jeny is a member of the Kusikuy Village Bank.  “Kusikuy” means “Be Happy” in Quechua.  Jeny is 21 years old and lives with her common-law husband and their son. 

Jeny and her husband have a restaurant in a rented space on a busy street.  They launched the restaurant three months ago and it has been going well so far.  The couple does all of the cooking and table service themselves.  

Jeny needs a loan of 1500 soles to buy an oven to cook chicken.  She dreams of expanding her business and providing her child with a good education.
 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Jeny  socia del Banco Comunal Kusikuy que significa Alégrate en quechua. 
Jeny es conviviente, tiene 21 años y 1 hijo, Jeny junto a su esposo tiene un restaurante en un local alquilado ubicado en una avenida concurrida, actividad que inicio hace 3 meses y le esta yendo bien, ella y su esposo se encargan de la cocina sy atención. 
Jeny necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de un horno para hornear pollos. Jeny sueña con ampliar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy an oven to cook chicken

loans.name: Santa Lucia Group

texts.es:
El comité de nombre Santa Lucia se conformó en fecha 17 de noviembre de 2008, gracias a que la actual Directora General, la Sra. Librada A. se contactó con la asesora para conocer mas acerca del programa del Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras, la misma una vez enterada de como funciona el dicho programa comentó con sus vecinas y amigas, y así logró junta a 15 mujeres, quienes se encuentran trabajando muy contentas con el programa.

El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 300.000, lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como venta de frutas y verduras, venta de carnes, venta de golosinas, venta de canastos, venta de ropas, venta de gallinas y huevos, venta de mandioca, venta de comestibles, venta de carbón, etc.

El detalle exacto de actividades que realiza cada integrante es como sigue:
1	Librada A.	Venta de carnes
2	Mariana G.	Despensa 
3	Justina O.	Venta de mercaderías 
4	Juana González	Venta de gallinas
5	Aurora R.	Venta de canasto
6	Hilda C.	Venta de golosinas
7	Sabina R.	Venta de frutas y verduras
8	Nilsa A.	Venta de canasto
9	Justina C.	Venta de carbón
10	Rosa R.	Venta de mandioca
11	Altagracia Jiménez	Trabajo en cestería.
12	Antonia N.	Venta de gallinas, frutas y verduras.
13	Cinthia González	Venta de canasto, frutas y verduras
14	María T.	Venta de gallinas y huevos.
15	Juana S.	Venta de ropas y comestibles

Todas las integrantes del comité asisten a las reuniones semanales y se encuentran muy a gusto trabajando en equipo con la Fundación Paraguaya.

El préstamo será destinado para la compra de carnes, compra de mercaderías para le despensa arroz, azúcar, yerba, lácteos, panificados, gaseosas, etc. compra de gallinas, compra de materia prima para la elaboración de canastos, compra de frutas y verduras, compra de huevos, compra de golosinas, compra de carbón, compra de mandioca, compra de ropas, compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de comidas, etc.
texts.en:
The Santa Lucia Committee was founded on November 17, 2008, thanks to Señora Librada A., who is currently the group's president. Señora Librada got in touch with one of Fundación Paraguaya's loan officers to find out more about the Committee of Entrepreneurial Women Program. Once she learned more about the program, she talked it over with her friends and neighbors, and was able to find 15 women, who today are working hard and are very happy with the program.

The average loan taken out by each member is 300,000 Paraguayan Guaranís, which will be used for a variety of business activities like fruit and vegetable sales, meat sales, candy sales, basket sales, clothing sales, chicken and egg sales, cassava sales, food sales, charcoal sales, etc.

Here is a list of each group member and their respective businesses:

1 Librada A., Meat sales
2 Mariana G., Grocery store
3 Justina O., Merchandise sales
4 Juana González, Chicken sales
5 Aurora R., Basket sales
6 Hilda C., Candy sales
7 Sabina R., Fruit and vegetable sales
8 Nilsa A., Basket sales
9 Justina C., Charcoal sales
10 Rosa R., Cassava sales
11 Altagracia Jiménez, Basket weaving
12 Antonia N., Sales of chickens, fruits and vegetables
13 Cinthia González, Sales of baskets, fruits and vegetables
14 María T., Chicken and egg sales
15 Juana S., Food and clothing sales

Each group member attends weekly meetings, and enjoys working as a team with Fundación Paraguaya.

The group members will use their loans to buy: meat, merchandise for grocery stores (sugar, rice, yerba mate, dairy products, bread, drinks), chickens, raw materials for basket-weaving, eggs, fruits and vegetables, sweets, charcoal, cassava, clothing, and ingredients to prepare meals with.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy meat, merchandise for grocery stores, chickens, raw materials for basket-weaving, eggs, fruits and vegetables, sweets, charcoal, cassava, clothing, and ingredients to prepare meals with.

loans.name: Clementina

texts.en:
Clementina is a member of the Sumaqcha Village Bank.  “Sumaqcha” means “Beautiful” in Quechua.  Clementina is 56 years old and married with six children.  

Clementina buys dry goods and ice cream in bulk, then travels to different regional markets to sell them.  At the markets, she buys hens, guinea pigs (a Peruvian delicacy) and grains, then resells them in markets and to restaurants around Ayacucho.  

Clementina needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy hens and guinea pigs.  Clementina’s dreams are to build her own home and for her children to finish their studies.
 
Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Clementita es socia del Banco Comunal Sumaqcha que significa Hermoso en quechua.   
Clementina es casada, tiene 56 años y 6 hijos, Clementina viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región, actividad que realiza todos los días, en donD. venD. abarrotes y helados que compra por mayor y D. las ferias compra gallinas, cuy, cereales que luego venD. en los mercados y restaurantes.
Clementina necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. gallinas y cuy.
Los sueños D. Clementina son construir su casa y que sus hijos culminen sus estudios.

loans.use: Buy hens and guinea pigs

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa is a member of the Sumaqcha Village Bank.  “Sumaqcha” means “Beautiful” in Quechua.  Vanessa is 23 years old and lives with her partner and their three children. 

Vanessa sells hardware-type items like padlocks, scissors, and shoe polish.  She sells her ware on foot in different local markets, and sometimes travels to regional markets too.  She works seven days a week.  

Vanessa needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy sparklers for Christmas.  Vanessa dreams of owning her own store, of building a home, and of providing her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Vanessa Es socia del Banco Comunal Sumaqcha que significa Hermoso en quechua.
Vanessa es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 3 hijos, Vanessa vende mercería como candados, betún, tijeras, entre otros productos, actividad que realiza todos los días de manera ambulatoria en diferentes mercados de la ciudad y algunas veces viaja a las ferias.
Venessa necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de luces de bengala para la navidad.
Vanessa sueña con tener una tienda, construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy sparklers for Christmas

loans.name: María Lourdes

texts.es:
La señora María Lourdes se ha destacado como una fiel comerciante de bisuterías las cuales son bolsas de regalos, lámparas de noche, peluches, collares y retrateras. Todos estos vendidos en su casa de habitación en la ciudad de León donde es originaria.

Ella hoy en día se dedica a su negocio con el propósito de llevar el sustento a su mesa y así beneficiar a su familia ya que por ser una dama viuda la responsabilidad del hogar recae sobre ella y por esto es que ha llegado a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los productos y así continuar en su negocio.
texts.en:
María Lourdes has proven herself to be an honest merchant of costume jewelry and gift bags, night lights, stuffed animals, necklaces and key rings. She sells all these items from her home in León, the city she is originally from. She works to put food on her table and support her family. As she is a widow, she is responsible for all of the household expenses and because of this she has come to Ceprodel to request a loan to buy merchandise and continue in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy gift bags for resale

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya is divorced. She has two married children and many grandchildren. She sells food at the market in Drogobych city. She does not have a kiosk that closes, so she needs to pack and unpack all her inventory every day. Her monthly gross income is 6,000 UAH; the profit is about 2,000 UAH.

Lidiya has been in this business for 8 years already. The business helped her to raise her children and help them to get married. Now the profit from this business allows Lidiya to help her growing grandchildren with their needs in food and clothing.

Lidiya would like to get a seasonal loan of 1,500 UAH to purchase more food she hopes to sell during the holiday season. Additional profit would help Lidiya to purchase some gifts for her family for the holiday.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is divorced and has two sons. She sells women's clothing at the market. Her monthly gross income is 7,000 UAH.

Olga has been in this business for 2 years. She decided to sell women's clothing because she just enjoys selling this kind of goods. Even though two years is not a big timespan for such business, Olga has already invested about 25,000 UAH in her inventory. This business is the only source of income for Olga and her two sons.

Olga would like to receive a loan of 6,000 UAH to increase her inventory. She believes that increasing her working capital can help her to make more money for her family and improve their financial situation.

loans.use: to increase her inventory

loans.name: Anzhella

texts.en:
Anzhella is married and has one teenage daughter. She sells children's and teenage clothing. Her monthly gross income is 20,000 UAH; the profit is 5,000 UAH.

Anzhella has been in this business for 5 years. Her business is located at a department store, where she rents some space. When Anzhella was just starting, she felt sure that children's and teenage clothing would always be in demand. She was right and her business grew. Being hard-working and a determined person, Anzhella desires to develop her business even more and  open a second business location.

Anzhella is asking for a loan of 1,500 UAH for 1 month. She believes this can be another little step in her business's growth.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Agapito Dudley

texts.es:
La “panadería Dios con nosotros” desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana abre sus puertas para brindar a sus clientes diferentes tipos de pan dulce y simple vendidos por su propietario el señor Agapito S. quien al centro de la mesa con su delantal y su gorro en la cabeza dirige la elaboración del pan que llevan a cabo sus trabajadores.

Se dedica a este negocio con mucho esfuerzo y tiene sus trabajadores que le apoyan en la elaboración del pan. Es importante destacar que antes de que se dedicara a este negocio era taxista pero por la difícil situación económica y con el deseo de superarse decidió iniciar poco a poco su panadería.

Hoy espera en Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con un crédito para lograr comprar la materia prima como lo es la harina, azúcar y otros ingredientes para elaborar el pan y comercializarlo en su panadería en el mercado central de la ciudad de León.
texts.en:
The bakery "God is with us" opens very early in the morning in order to offer its clients different types of pastries and breads sold by its owner, Mr. Agapito S.. Mr. S. is pictured above in the center of the table with the chef's hat. He directs his helpers in the making of the bread. He works very hard in this business, along with his employees who help him in making bread. It is important to note that before this, he worked as a taxi driver but due to the difficult economic situation and his desire to better himself he eventually decided to open his bakery. Today, he hopes to benefit from a loan from Ceprodel in order to buy raw materials such as flour, sugar and other ingredients to make the bread and sell it in his bakery located in the central market of the city of León.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour and sugar

loans.name: Alla

texts.en: With over five years of experience as an entrepreneur, Alla V. sells clothing items in the central city market of her hometown, Kahovka. Alla is married. She works with professionalism and dedication. She is optimistic and hard-working, with plans to increase her clothing sales business. Alla has been a client of Nadiya Ukraine for a couple of years. A successful micro-finance entrepreneur, she has maintained a perfect credit history. She is currently seeking a loan of 4,000 Grivnas to purchase new inventory and expand her business.

loans.use: To generate additional profit

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei is married with a teenage daughter. He is a businessman from Kamenka. He runs a cosmetics and perfume sales business in the local city market. Sergei has had much experience working with this type of merchandise and has gained a good reputation among his customers and colleagues. Sergei has been working as a market vendor for 15 years. Currently, he already has about 40,000 Grivnas invested in inventory. His income is about 3,000-4,000 Grivnas a month. 

Sergei has repaid 9 previous loans to Nadiya Ukraine without any delinquencies. This time he is seeking a 5000 Grivna loan to finish construction of a new vending kiosk, increase assorted merchandise, and attract new potential customers as a result. Sergei’s family is very supportive of his business endeavors. They try to help him as much as they can. Sergei is hoping to repay the current loan in 6 months.

loans.use: To open and stock a new vending location

loans.name: Dolores De La Concepción

texts.es:
La señora Dolores de la Concepción es originaria de la ciudad de León donde muy alegremente comercializa frutas desde muy temprano por la mañana en una localidad a la intemperie en el mercado central por lo que requiere de inversión para obtener un tramo donde vender sus frutas y no estar exponiéndose al sol y a la lluvia.

Por estas razones es que ella ha acudido a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con un crédito que le permita en este momento la compra de las frutas para su respectiva comercialización y para continuar brindándole mejores condiciones a sus tres hijos en edades escolares.
texts.en:
Dolores de la Concepcion is originally from the city of Leon where she very happily markets fruits beginning early in the morning in a location in the central open-air market. This enterprise requires an investment in order to obtain a stall where she can sell her fruits and not be exposed to the sun and the rain. For this reason she has approached Ceprodel in order to obtain a loan which will allow her to purchase fruits for her business and in order to continue providing her school-aged children with the best possible conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits

loans.name: Anatoliy

texts.en:
Anatoliy is married and has one son. He manufactures wooden objects with his hands. He has been in this business for 8 years already. Anatoliy enjoys making objects out of wood and other people enjoy his craftsmanship, too. They order many different things from Anatoliy. Anatoliy has very few competitors. This allows his business to be unique and very profitable.

Anatoliy would like to receive 6,000 UAH to purchase materials for his work. He needs to buy them in bulk. Anatoliy's work not only gives joy to him and his customers but allows him to take good care of his family.

loans.use: to purchase materials for woodworking

loans.name: Reyna De Los Angeles

texts.es: La Sr. Reyna tiene 32 años de edad, habita en  un barrio de la capital de Managua llamado Laureles Norte, casada su esposo es técnico de electrónica, tiene un niña 4 años de edad, los planes para su familia es terminar la construcción de su casa, acondicionándola y ofrecerle un patrimonio a su hija para un futuro. Doña  Reyna se desempeña como profesora en tres colegios y tres horarios diferentes de la capital con cinco años de experiencia de enseñar pues trabaja en tres turnos para obtener más ingresos, Sus objetivos en el ámbito laboral es seguir ofreciendo su servicio de profesora en otras arias de la educación. Gracias a los préstamos de Afodenic lograra comprar materiales de construcción como: cemento, hierro, bloque y ladrillo, ofreciéndole para hacer su casa de concreto ya que es de zinc, y desea tener una casa digna y segura para su familia.
texts.en:
Reyna is 32 years old, lives in a neighborhood in the capital of Managua called Laureles Norte, is married to an electrical technician and has a 4-year-old daughter. Her future plans for her family include finishing the construction of their home, fixing it up, and they hope to be able to save some money so that their daughter can have a future. Reyna works as a teacher is three schools and three different schedules in the capital. She has five years of experience but works three jobs in order to have more income. Her career objective is to continue providing her services as a teacher in other areas of the education field. Thanks to the loans from Afodenic she will be able to purchase construction materials such as cement, iron, cement block, and brick, allowing her to make her house concrete instead of the current material which is zinc. She hopes to have a dignified and safe home for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kristy Placido, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials in order to construct her home of concrete.

loans.name: Los Olivos Group

texts.en:
The Los Olivos (“The Olive Trees”) Village Bank has 13 members, all women, and is beginning its second loan cycle. The group is named after the Los Olivos neighborhood, where all of its members live. Meetings are held at the home of one of the group members. The women are involved in a variety of different businesses. Some sell dry goods, cheese or cosmetics from a catalogue, while others work as cosmetologists, make and sell textiles, or prepare meals and juices to sell.

Some sell from door to door or on foot, while others sell in the city’s markets. The group members are requesting different loan amounts: 300 soles (US$ 100), 450 soles (US$ 150), 600 (US$ 200) or 900 (US$ 300) soles. Los Olivos is requesting a total of 6,450 soles in loans.

The loans will be invested to buy sugar, rice, milk, pasta, various fruits, wool, and dyes. Some of the group members’ dreams are to own their own homes, to improve their homes, to expand their businesses, and to proviD. their children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal Los Olivos inicia su segundo ciclo con 13 socias. Todas las socias son del barrio D. Los Olivos, nombre que lleva el Banco Comunal, las reuniones se realizan en el domicilio D. alguna socia.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios, como L. venta D. abarrotes en general, quesos, cosméticos por catálogos, brindan servicios D. cosmetología, elaboran textiles y preparación D. jugos y comidas. Sus ventas los realizan D. manera ambulatoria, D. casa en casa y en los mercados D. L. ciudad.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles y 900 soles, haciendo un total D. 6,450 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.

Los préstamos lo invertirán en L. compra D. azúcar, arroz, fideo, leche, quesos, frutas variadas, lanas, tintes. Los sueños D. las socias es tener casa propia, mejorar su casa, ampliar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buy sugar, rice, milk, pasta, various fruits, wool, and dyes

loans.name: Musuq Wasi Group

texts.en:
The Musuq Wasi (“New House” in Quechua) Village Bank is a group loan maD. up of 18 members who have just begun their 14th loan cycle. All the group members are from the Muyurina community, a small town located in a valley 30 minutes outsiD. of the city of Ayacucho. Most members of the community are farmers or raise small animals. Many grow a variety of vegetables, which they then sell in the Abastos Market in the city of Ayacucho.

The group members are requesting different loan amounts, like 300 (US$ 100), 450 (US$ 150), 600 (US$ 200) or 900 (US$ 300) soles. Musuq Wasi is requesting a total of 11,550 soles in loans. The loans will be used to buy seeds, fertilizer, medicines, sugar, rice, noodles, and to pay farmhands. Some of the group members’ dreams are for their businesses to prosper, to produce mO., for their children to graduate from college with professional degrees, and to own homes of their own.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

El Banco Comunal Musuq Wasi que en Quechua quiere decir Casa Nueva, es un Banco Comunal que inicia el ciclo 14 con 18 socias. Todas las socias son D. la comunidad D. Muyurina que es un pequeño valle ubicado a 30 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, la actividad principal D. la zona es la agricultura y la crianza D. animales menores, producen verduras variadas, que luego venden en el mercado D. abasto D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Las socias realizan diferentes negocios, en mayor parte son agricultoras D. verduras, venta D. combustibles, crianza D. animales, venta D. abarrotes. Sus ventas los realizan en algunas oportunidades en la misma comunidad y también en los mercados D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 300 soles, 450 soles, 600 soles y 900 soles, haciendo un total D. 11,550 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.
